revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Orphan|date=June 2013}}
The '''France–Pakistan atomic energy framework''', or also known as '''France–Pakistan nuclear deal''', is a bilateral energy treaty signed by the governments of [[Cabinet of France|France]] and [[Government of Pakistan|Pakistan]] on 15 May 2009.<ref name="BBC Pakistan, 2009">{{cite news|last=Staff reports|title=Pakistan in 'French nuclear deal'|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8052587.stm|accessdate=17 September 2012|newspaper=BBC Pakistan, 2009|date= 15 May 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author = Francois Murphy |title=Pakistan Asserts French Backing; Cites Support for Nuclear Deal,|newspaper=Boston Globe,|date=16 May 2009, Lexis-Nexis.|accessdate=17 September 2012|url=http://www.nti.org/media/pdfs/pakistan_nuclear.pdf?_=1316466791}}</ref> The framework of this agreement was a 15 May 2009, in a joint press statement of President [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] and President [[Asif Ali Zardari]], under which France agreed to provide assistance to improve the [[nuclear safety]] of its [[Nuclear power in Pakistan|nuclear power]] installations and related civilian nuclear facilities under [[International Atomic Energy Agency]] (IAEA) safeguards and,as well as the transfer full civilian-based [[nuclear technology]] to Pakistan.<ref name="BBC Pakistan, 2009"/><ref name="Agence France-Presse,">{{cite news|last=AFP|title=France offers Pakistan nuclear energy help|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iZ57_cSGpmiOKuVA6d5kN79aw9hg|accessdate=17 September 2012|newspaper=Agence France-Presse,|date=15 May 2009}}</ref>
In contrast to [[U.S.–India Civil Nuclear Agreement|Indo-American nuclear agreement]], this framework restricted itself to only to co-operate in the field of "[[nuclear safety]]", as quoted by the [[French Foreign Ministry]].<ref name="NTI (The Hindu)"/> While [[Foreign Office of Pakistan|foreign service officers]] and the Foreign minister [[Shah Mahmood Qureshi]] outlined what they termed as "significant development"; however, a French official stated that his nation has "no intention" of pursuing a civilian nuclear trade deal, roughly equivalent to [[Indo-US nuclear deal|Indo-US deal]], with Pakistan.<ref name="NTI (The Hindu)">{{cite news|last=Staff|title=Back to Global Security Newswire Home About Global Security Newswire Contact Us France Plans No Civilian Nuclear Deal With Pakistan, Official Says|url=http://www.nti.org/gsn/article/france-plans-no-civilian-nuclear-deal-with-pakistan-official-says/|accessdate=17 September 2012|newspaper=NTI (The Hindu)|date=24 November 2009}}</ref>
==Overview and background==
Since 1967, France has emerged as the biggest defence contractor of Pakistan, despite its [[India-France relations|good and relatively close relations]] with India.<ref>{{cite web|title=See [[India-France relations]]}}</ref> Pakistan is one of three original participant states (others being [[India]] and [[Israel]]) that refused to be signatory of the [[Nuclear Proliferation Treaty|NPT]].<ref>See: [[Nuclear Proliferation Treaty]]</ref> On March 1976, France and Pakistan signed a mutual agreement for the supply of plutonium-based [[nuclear reprocessing]] plant at the [[Chasma Pakistan|Chasma]].<ref name="Council on Foreign Relations">{{cite book|last=Tahrir-Khalil|first=Shirine R.|title=India, Pakistan and the United States|year=1997|publisher=Council on Foreign Relations|location=New York|isbn=0-87609-199-0|pages=72–76|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=srCLD-PXl-gC&pg=PA72&lpg=PA72&dq=france+pakistan+nuclear+deal&source=bl&ots=Z1Ku11okX_&sig=upK3myyBe00_k2wCp5OvZ5Am7OM&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ZohXUMS0LojviQKvwYCwAw&ved=0CC8QuwUwAA#v=onepage&q=france%20pakistan%20nuclear%20deal&f=true|accessdate=17 September 2012|format=google book|chapter=Preventing Proliferation}}</ref> However, this deal came under attack from various countries, particularly the United States, for two reasons.<ref name="Council on Foreign Relations"/> First, Pakistan under Prime minister [[Zulfikar Ali Bhutto]] was putting efforts to gain success in its [[Pakistan and Nuclear Weapons|atomic bomb project]].<ref name="Council on Foreign Relations"/> Second, the French deal was not completely under the inspection of the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]] (IAEA).<ref name="Council on Foreign Relations"/> The United States pressed full scope and built momentum on France to re-consider its decision, while on other hand, Bhutto threatened the France that the future contracts would be contingent on its first fulfilling the "contractual obligation" to the legally obliged agreement.<ref name="Council on Foreign Relations"/> In 1976, [[Henry Kissinger]] arrived Pakistan with tough message which became publicly known in Pakistan.<ref name="Council on Foreign Relations"/> In a short span of time, France under pressured by the various countries, cancelled the project with Pakistan.<ref name="Council on Foreign Relations"/>
==Clauses and scope==
Despite France's willingness to give a green signal for this agreement, the confusion remains over what was agreed.<ref name="BBC Pakistan, 2009"/> The officials of Pakistan's Foreign ministry had undertaken to supply Pakistan with "civilian nuclear technology", the French officials stressed on the fact that "France had agreed only to co-operate in the field of "nuclear safety".<ref name="BBC Pakistan, 2009"/> Although, in an official press French President Nicolas Sarkozy marked to his counterpart that "France wanted Pakistan to have a wide-ranging deal to buy nuclear equipment" like the one obtained by its rival India,<ref name=Reuters>{{cite web|title=Sarkozy wants India-style nuclear deal for Pakistan|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2009/05/15/pakistan-france-nuclear-idINLF40083320090515|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=18 September 2012}}</ref> but later spokesman for the French presidency was careful to rein in expectations and much of the details were closed to the public.<ref name="BBC Pakistan, 2009"/>
==Notes== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:France-Pakistan Atomic Energy Framework}} [[Category:Energy treaties]] [[Category:Nuclear safety and security]] [[Category:France–Pakistan relations]] [[Category:Nuclear technology in Pakistan]] [[Category:2009 in law]] [[Category:Government of Yousaf Raza Gillani]] [[Category:Treaties of Pakistan]] [[Category:Bilateral treaties of France]] [[Category:Secret treaties]] [[Category:Nuclear technology treaties]]

[[Image:Bigrock.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|Big Rock in [[Okotoks]], [[Alberta]]]]
A '''glacial erratic''' is a piece of [[Rock (geology)|rock]] that differs from the size and type of rock native to the area in which it rests. "[[wiktionary:erratic|Erratics]]" take their name from the Latin word ''[[wikt:errare#Latin|errare]]'' (to wander), and are carried by [[glacier|glacial ice]], often over distances of hundreds of kilometres. Erratics can range in size from pebbles to large boulders such as [[Big Rock (glacial erratic)|Big Rock]] ({{convert|15000|t|ST|disp=or}}) in [[Alberta]]. [[File:Schokland, zwerfsteen bij ingang museum-restaurant foto6 2013-04-28 13.02.jpg|thumb|Glacial erratics from Norway on [[Schokland]] in the Netherlands.]] Geologists identify erratics by studying the rocks surrounding the position of the erratic and the composition of the erratic itself. Erratics are significant because: *They can be transported by glaciers, and they are thereby one of a series of indicators which mark the path of prehistoric glacier movement. Their lithographic origin can be traced to the parent bedrock, allowing for confirmation of the ice flow route. *They can be transported by [[ice rafting]]. This allows quantification of the extent of glacial flooding resulting from ice dam failure which release the waters stored in [[proglacial lake]]s such as [[Lake Missoula]]. Erratics released by ice-rafts that were stranded and subsequently melt, dropping their load, allow characterization of the high-water marks for transient floods in areas like temporary [[Lake Lewis]]. *Erratics dropped by [[iceberg]]s melting in the ocean can be used to track Antarctic and Arctic-region glacial movements for periods prior to record retention. Also known as [[dropstone]]s, these can be correlated with ocean temperatures and levels to better understand and calibrate [[Global climate model|models of the global climate]].<ref name=Bard2004>{{Cite journal |last=Bard |first=Edouard |language=French |title=Effet de serre et glaciations, une perspective historique |trans-title=Greenhouse effect and ice ages: historical perspective |journal=Comptes Rendus Geoscience |volume=336 |issue=7–8 |pages=603–638 |date=June 2004 |doi=10.1016/j.crte.2004.02.005 |bibcode=2004CRGeo.336..603B }}</ref>
==Formation of erratics== [[Image:Erratics-Cascades-PB110028.JPG|thumb|left|Multiple erratics on the terminal moraine of the Okanagon Lobe. Cascade mountains in the background.]] [[Image:Doane Rock.jpeg|upright|thumb|[[Doane Rock]], at [[Cape Cod National Seashore]]]] The term "erratic" is commonly used to refer to erratic blocks, which Geikie describes as: "large masses of rock, often as big as a house, that have been transported by glacier-ice, and have been lodged in a prominent position in the glacier valleys or have been scattered over hills and plains. And examination of their mineralogical character leads the identification of their sources…".<ref name= Geikie1882>{{Cite journal | last = Geikie | first = Sir Archibald | authorlink = | title = Textbook of geology | journal = | volume = | issue = | pages = | publisher = | location = | year = 1882 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=QzYAAAAAQAAJ&dq=erratic+glacier | issn = | doi = | id = | accessdate = 12 December 2009}}</ref> In geology, an erratic is material moved by geologic forces from one location to another, usually by a glacier.
Erratics are formed by glacial [[Erosion|ice erosion]] resulting from the movement of ice. [[Glacier]]s erode by multiple processes: abrasion/scouring, [[Plucking (glaciation)|plucking]], ice thrusting and [[ice lens|glacially-induced spalling]]. Glaciers crack pieces of bedrock off in the process of plucking, producing the larger erratics. In an abrasion process, debris in the basal ice scrapes along the bed, polishing and gouging the underlying rocks, similar to sandpaper on wood, producing smaller [[glacial till]]. In ice thrusting, the glacier freezes to its bed, then as it surges forward, it moves large sheets of frozen sediment at the base along with the glacier. Glacially-induced spalling occurs when [[ice lens]] formation with the rocks below the glacier spall off layers of rock, providing smaller debris which is ground into the glacial basal material to become till.<ref name=Bell2008>{{Cite journal | last = Bell | first = Robin E. | authorlink = | title = The role of subglacial water in ice-sheet mass balance | journal = [[Nature Geoscience]] | volume = 1 | issue = 5802 | pages = 297–304| publisher = | location = | date = 27 April 2008 | url = | doi= 10.1038/ngeo186| id = | bibcode=2008NatGe...1..297B}}</ref><ref name=Rempel2008>{{Cite journal | last = Rempel | first = A. W. | authorlink = | title = A theory for ice-till interactions and sediment entrainment beneath glaciers | journal = Journal of Geophysical Research | volume = 113 | pages = F01013| publisher = [[American Geophysical Union]]. | location = | year =2008 | url = | doi= 10.1029/2007JF000870| id = | bibcode=2008JGRF..11301013R | issue = 113=}}</ref>
Evidence supports another option for creation of erratics as well, rock avalanches onto the upper surface of the glacier (supraglacial). Rock avalanche–supraglacial transport occurs when the glacier undercuts a rock face, which fails by avalanche onto the upper surface of the glacier. The characteristics of rock avalanche–supraglacial transport includes:<ref name=Evenson2009>{{Cite journal | last = Evenson | first = Edward B. | authorlink = |author2=Patrick A. Burkhart |author3=John C. Gosse |author4=Gregory S. Baker |author5=Dan Jackofsky |author6=Andres Meglioli |author7=Ian Dalziel |author8=Stefan Kraus |author9=Richard B. Alley |author10=Claudio Berti | title = Enigmatic boulder trains, supraglacial rock avalanches, and the origin of "Darwin's boulders," Tierra del Fuego | journal = GSA Today | volume = 19 | issue = 12 | pages = 4–10 | publisher = [[The Geological Society of America]] | location = | date = December 2009 | url = http://www.geosociety.org/gsatoday/archive/19/12/article/i1052-5173-19-12-4.htm| doi = 10.1130/GSATG72A.1 | id = | accessdate = 14 December 2009}}</ref> :*Monolithologic composition – a cluster of boulders of similar composition are frequently found in close proximity. Commingling of the multiple [[Lithology|lithologies]] normally present throughout the glaciated basin, has not occurred.<ref name=Evenson2009/> :*Angularity – the supraglacially transported rocks tend to be rough and irregular, with no sign of subglacial abrasion. The sides of boulders are roughly planar, suggesting that some surfaces may be original fracture planes.<ref name=Evenson2009/> :*Great size – the size distribution of the boulders tends to be skewed toward larger boulders than those produced subglacially.<ref name=Evenson2009/> :*Surficial positioning of the boulders – the boulders are positioned on the surface of glacial deposits, as opposed to partially or totally buried.<ref name=Evenson2009/> :*Restricted areal extents – the boulder fields tend to have limited areal extent; the boulders cluster together, consistent with the boulders landing on the surface of the glacier and subsequently deposited on top of the glacial drift.<ref name=Evenson2009/> :*Orientations – the boulders may be close enough that original fracture planes can be matched.<ref name=Evenson2009/> :*Locations of the boulder trains – the boulders appear in rows, trains or clusters along the [[lateral moraines]] as opposed to being located on the [[terminal moraine]] or in the general glacial field.<ref name=Evenson2009/>
===Glacier-borne erratic=== [[File:Upsala Glacier, Argentina.jpg|thumb|right|Two icebergs clearly retain fragments of the [[moraine]] (rock debris) that forms a dark line along the upper surface of the glacier. The inclusion of the moraine illustrates how land-based rocks and sediment are carried by ice.]] Erratics provide an important tool in characterizing the directions of glacier flows, which are routinely reconstructed used on a combination of [[moraine]]s, [[esker]]s, [[drumlin]]s, meltwater channels, and similar data. Erratic distributions and glacial till properties allow for identification of the source rock from which they derive, which confirms the flow direction, particularly when the erratic source outcrop is unique to a limited locality. Erratic materials may be transported by multiple glacier flows prior to their deposition, which can complicate the reconstruction of the glacial flow.<ref name=Evans2005>{{Cite journal |last=Evans |first=David J.A |author2=Chris D. Clark |author3=Wishart A. Mitchell |title=The last British Ice Sheet: A review of the evidence utilised in the compilation of the Glacial Map of Britain |journal=Earth-Science Reviews |volume=70 |issue=3–4 |page=253 |publisher=Copyright © 2005 Elsevier B.V |date=May 2005 |url=http://dro.dur.ac.uk/1216/ |doi=10.1016/j.earscirev.2005.01.001 |bibcode=2005ESRv...70..253E |accessdate=10 September 2013}}</ref>
===Ice-rafted erratic=== Glacial ice entrains debris of varying sizes from small particles to extremely large masses of rock. This debris is transported to the coast by glacier ice and released during the production, drift and melting of [[iceberg]]s. The rate of debris release by ice depends upon the size of the ice mass in which it is carried as well as the temperature of the ocean through which the ice floe passes.<ref name=Bond1999>{{Cite journal |last=Bond |first=Gerard |author2=[[Hartmut Heinrich]] |author3=Wallace Broecker |author4=Laurent Labeyrie |author5=Jerry McManus |author6=John Andrews |author7=Sylvain Huon |author8=Ruediger Jantschik |author9=Silke Clasen |author10=Christine Simet |author11=Kathy Tedesco |author12=Mieczyslawa Klas |author13=Georges Bonani |author14=Susan Ivy | title = Evidence for massive discharges of icebergs into the North Atlantic ocean during the last glacial period |journal=Nature |volume=360 |issue=6401 |pages=245–249 |year=1992 |doi=10.1038/360245a0}}</ref><ref name=Tripatti2007 >{{Cite journal |last=Tripatia |first=Aradhna K. |author2=Robert A. Eagleb |author3=Andrew Mortonc |author4=Julian A. Dowdeswelld |author5=Katie L. Atkinsone |author6=Yannick Bahéf |author7=Caroline F. Dawbera |author8=Emma Khadung |author9=Ruth M.H. Shawa |author10=Oliver Shorttleh |author11=Lavaniya Thanabalasundarami| title = Evidence for glaciation in the Northern Hemisphere back to 44 Ma from ice-rafted debris in the Greenland Sea | journal = Earth and Planetary Science Letters | volume = 265 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 112–122 | publisher = Elsevier B.V. | location = | year = 2007 | url = | doi = 10.1016/j.epsl.2007.09.045 | id = | accessdate = | bibcode=2008E&PSL.265..112T}}</ref>
[[Image:Yeager-Rock-Erractic-PB110039.JPG|thumb|alt=This photo shows an automobile passing in front of a rock which is essentially fully exposed. The rock has a rough, dark surface indicating it is weathered basalt and is roughly circular in exposed cross-section. The rock is immediately adjacent to a roadway – the road cut removed much of the earth from one side of it exposing it – from the excavation it is evident that the rock sits on a mound of glacial till. The rock is approximately 2 times the length of the car (i.e., ≈9 meters) in one direction and 5 times the height of the car in the other direction (i.e., ≈9 meters). Since the rock has not tipped onto the road and no structural support is provided, it must be approximately as deep as it is wide and high. Since the density of basalt is 3 grams per cubic centimeter, this puts the mass of the rock at about 400 to 500 metric tons (consistent with the references). |[[Yeager Rock]], a {{convert|400|MT|ST|adj=on}} boulder on the Waterville Plateau, [[Washington (state)|Washington]]. Although transported by a glacier, this boulder is not a true erratic because it is of the same lithology of the underlying, till-blanketed, bedrock. Note the glacial till below the rock.]]
Sediments from the late [[Pleistocene]] period lying on the floor of the [[North Atlantic]] show a series of layers (referred to at Heinrich layers) which contain ice-rafted debris. They were formed between 14,000 & 70,000 years before the present. The deposited debris can be traced back to the origin by both the nature of the materials released and the continuous path of debris release. Some paths extend more than {{convert|3000|km|mi}} distant from the point at which the ice floes originally broke free.<ref name=Bond1999/>
The location and altitude of ice-rafted boulders relative to the modern landscape has been used to identify the highest level of water in proglacial lakes (e.g., [[Lake Musselshell]] in central [[Montana]]) and temporary lakes (e.g., [[Lake Lewis]] in [[Washington (state)|Washington]] state. Ice-rafted debris is deposited when the iceberg strands on the shore and subsequently melts, or drops out of the ice floe as it melts. Hence all erratic deposits are deposited below the actual high water level of the lake; however the measured altitude of ice-rafted debris can be used to estimate the lake surface elevation.
[[Image:Angular glacial erratic on Lambert Dome-750px.jpg|thumb|right|Angular glacial erratic on [[Lembert Dome]].]] This is accomplished by recognizing that on a fresh-water lake, the iceberg floats until the volume of its ice-rafted debris exceeds 5% of the volume of the iceberg. Therefore, a correlation between the iceberg size and the boulder size can be established. For example, {{convert|1.5|m|ft|adj=on}} diameter boulder can be carried by a {{convert|3|m|ft|adj=on}} high iceberg and could be found stranded at higher elevations than a {{convert|2|m|ft|adj=on}} boulder which requires a {{convert|4|m|ft|adj=on}} high iceberg.<ref name= Davisa2005>{{Cite journal | last = Davisa | first = Niole K. |author2=William W. Locke III |author3=Kenneth L. Pierce |author4=Robert C. Finkel | title = Glacial Lake Musselshell: Late Wisconsin slackwater on the Laurentide ice margin in central Montana, USA | journal = Geomorphology | volume = 75 | issue = 3–4 | pages = 330–345 | publisher = Elsevier B.V. | location = | date = May 2006 | url = | doi = 10.1016/j.geomorph.2005.07.021 | id = |bibcode = 2006Geomo..75..330D }}</ref>
===Large erratics=== [[Image:Letipea hiidrahn.jpg|thumb|Glacial erratic [[Ehalkivi]] with overground volume {{convert|930|m3|cuyd}} (weight approximately {{convert|2500|MT|ST|disp=or}}) in [[Estonia]]]] [[Image:Pl-pomerania-lake-Kamienne.jpg|thumb|left|300px|Glacial erratic in [[Kashubia]]]] [[Image:Glacial erratic in alaska.gif|thumb|Area exposed by the retreat of [[Alaska]]'s [[Steller Glacier]] in August 1996, the westernmost part of [[Bering Glacier]]'s [[Ice piedmont|piedmont]] lobe. The ground surface is covered by glacial [[sediment]] deposited as lodgement and [[ablation]] [[till]]. The erratic is an angular, {{convert|20|ft|m|adj=on}}-high piece of [[gneiss]]. Bering Glacier, Alaska flows through [[Wrangell-Saint Elias National Park]]]] Large erratics consisting of slabs of bedrock that have been lifted and transported by glacier ice to subsequently be stranded above thin glacial or fluvioglacial deposits are referred to as glacial floes, rafts (schollen) or erratic megablocks. Erratic megablocks have typical length to thickness ratios on the order of 100 to 1. These megablocks may be found partially exposed or completely buried by till and are clearly [[allochthon]]us, since they overlay [[glacial till]]. Megablocks can be so large that they are mistaken for bedrock until underlying glacial or fluvial sediments are identified by drilling or excavation. Such erratic megablocks greater than {{convert|1|km2|acre}} in area and {{convert|30|m|ft}} in thickness can be found on the [[Canadian Prairies]], [[Poland]], [[England]], [[Denmark]] and [[Sweden]]. One erratic megablock located in [[Saskatchewan]] is {{convert|30|x|38|km|mi}} (and up to {{convert|100|m|ft|disp=or}} thick). Their sources can be identified by locating the bedrock from which they were separated; several rafts from Poland and Alberta were determined to have been transported over {{convert|300|km|mi}} from their source.<ref name= Talbot1999>{{Cite journal | last = Talbot | first = Christopher J. | authorlink = | title = Ice ages and nuclear waste isolation | journal = Engineering Geology | volume = 52 | issue = 3–4 | pages = 177–192 | publisher = Elsevier Science | location = | date = April 1999 | url = | doi = 10.1016/S0013-7952(99)00005-8 | id = }}</ref>
===Nonglacial erratics=== In geology an erratic is any material which is not native to the immediate locale but has been transported from elsewhere. The most common examples of erratics are associated with glacial transport, either by direct glacier-borne transport or by ice rafting. However, other erratics have been identified as the result of [[kelp]] holdfasts, which have been documented to transport rocks up to {{convert|40|cm|in}} in diameter, rocks entangled in the roots of drifting logs, and even in transport of stones accumulated in the stomachs of [[pinniped]]s during foraging.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Paduan | first = Jennifer B. | authorlink = |author2=David A. Clague |author3=Alicé S. Davis | title = Erratic continental rocks on volcanic seamounts off the US west coast | journal = Marine Geology | volume = 246 | issue =1 | pages = 1–8 | publisher = | location = | date = 28 November 2007 | url = | doi = 10.1016/j.margeo.2007.07.007 | id = | bibcode =2007MGeol.246....1P}} </ref>
==History== During the 18th century, erratics were deemed a major geological paradox. Erratics were once considered evidence of a vast flood approximately 10,000 years ago,{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} similar to the legendary floods described in the texts of [[ancient civilizations]] throughout the world. Ancient [[legend]]s of an epic flood come from many cultures including [[Mesoamerican]], [[Sumer]]ian ([[Epic of Gilgamesh]]), [[Hebrews|Hebrew]] ([[Old Testament]]) and [[Indus Valley Civilization|Indian]] culture. Among others, the Swiss politician, jurist and theologican {{ill|Bernhard Friedrich Kuhn|de}} saw glaciers as a possible solution as early as 1788. However the idea of ice ages and glaciation as a geological force took a while to be accepted. [[Ignaz Venetz]] (1788 — 1859), a Swiss engineer, naturalist, and glaciologist was one of the first scientists to recognize glaciers as a major force in shaping the earth.
In the 19th century, many scientists came to favor erratics as evidence for the end of the [[Last Glacial Maximum]] ([[ice age]]) 10,000 years ago, rather than a flood. [[Geologist]]s have suggested that [[landslide]]s or rockfalls initially dropped the rocks on top of glacial ice. The glaciers continued to move, carrying the rocks with them. When the ice melted, the erratics were left in their present locations.
Charles Lyell's ''Principles of Geology'' (v. 1, 1830)<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=AOcJAAAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=charles+lyell+principles+of+geology&cd=2#v=onepage&q=&f=false ''Principles of Geology''], Volume 1; Sir Charles Lyell - Geology - 1830</ref> provided an early description of the erratic which is consistent with the modern understanding. [[Louis Agassiz]] was the first to scientifically propose that the Earth had been subject to a past [[ice age]].<ref name="evans 1887">E.P. Evans: "[http://rs6.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/ncps:@field(DOCID+@lit(ABQ7578-0145-13))::|The The Authorship of the Glacial Theory]", ''North American review'' Volume 145, Issue 368, July 1887. Accessed on February 25, 2008.</ref> In the same year, he was elected a foreign member of the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]]. Prior to this proposal, [[Johann Wolfgang von Goethe|Goethe]], [[Horace-Bénédict de Saussure|de Saussure]], [[Ignaz Venetz|Venetz]], [[Jean de Charpentier]], [[Karl Friedrich Schimper]] and others had made the [[glacier]]s of the Alps the subjects of special study, and Goethe,<ref name="goethe">{{cite book|url=http://www.igsoc.org/journal/5/41/igs_journal_vol05_issue041_pg751-754.pdf|title=Early discoverers XXII, Goethe-Discoverer of the ice age. Journal of glaciology|last=Cameron|first=Dorothy|year=1964}}</ref> Charpentier as well as Schimper<ref name="evans 1887" /> had even arrived at the conclusion that the erratic blocks of alpine rocks scattered over the slopes and summits of the [[Jura Mountains]] had been moved there by glaciers.
[[Charles Darwin]] published extensively on geologic phenomena including the distribution of erratic boulders. In his accounts written during the voyage of {{HMS|Beagle}}, Darwin observed a number of large erratic boulders of notable size south of the [[Strait of Magellan]], [[Tierra del Fuego]] and attributed them to ice rafting from [[Antarctica]]. Recent research suggests that they are more likely the result of glacial ice flows carrying the boulders to their current locations.<ref>Edward B. Evenson, Patrick A. Burkhart, John C. Gosse, Gregory S. Baker, Dan Jackofsky, Andres Meglioli, Ian Dalziel, Stefan Kraus, Richard B. Alley, Claudio Berti; "Enigmatic boulder trains, supraglacial rock avalanches, and the origin of "Darwin's boulders", Tierra del Fuego; GSA Today; Volume 19 Issue 12 (December 2009); pp. 4-10</ref>
==Examples==
===Glacier-borne erratics=== [[File:Mixed-Eratics-PB110053.JPG|thumbnail|Example of mixed erratics. The boulder in the foreground is basalt. The boulder across the fence is granite.]]
Examples of erratics include:
* [[The Hitching Stone]] in [[Yorkshire]], [[England]]. It’s the largest erratic block in the county.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bradfordhistorical.org.uk/boundary.html|title=On the Bradford District's Western Boundary|website=www.bradfordhistorical.org.uk|access-date=2018-06-02}}</ref> * [[Big Rock (glacial erratic)|Big Rock]] near [[Okotoks]], [[Alberta]], Canada. It is the largest erratic in the [[Foothills Erratics Train]]. * [[Plymouth Rock]], the site in [[Plymouth, Massachusetts]] that the ''[[Mayflower]]'' [[Pilgrim (Plymouth Colony)|Pilgrims]] landed in 1620. It is an important symbol in American history. * Indian Rock in [[Montebello, New York]] is a large glacial erratic boulder of granite gneiss, formed in the Proterozoic (Precambrian) era, 1.2 billion to 800 million years ago. It is estimated to weigh ≈17,300 tons. The source area for the boulder was nearby in the Ramapo Mountains-Hudson Highlands. The boulder rests upon glacial outwash which in turn lies atop Triassic sedimentary red beds (sandstone and shale) of the Newark Basin (circa 145 million years old). The rock was carried to its current location by the internal flow of the continental ice sheet during the last glacial maximum, circa 21,000 years ago. The base of the continental glacier scoured the bedrock terrain across which it moved, thus plucking large and small blocks of rock from their position in the Ramapo Mountains and Hudson Highlands. Indian Rock got as far as Rockland County before being liberated by the ice and deposited along with gravels shifted by glacial meltwater. * [[Bleasdell Boulder]], southern Ontario was described "glacial" in origin by Reverend William Bleasdell in 1872<ref>{{cite journal |last=Bleasdell |first=Rev. William |title=On Modern Glacial Action in Canada |journal=Quarterly Journal of the Geological Society |year=1872 |volume=28 |pages=392–396 |doi=10.1144/GSL.JGS.1872.028.01-02.45 |url=http://jgslegacy.lyellcollection.org/cgi/content/abstract/28/1-2/392}}</ref> * [[Fantastic Erratic]], a [[fern]]-covered erratic the size of a garage, is found on [[Cougar Mountain]] near [[Seattle]]. * [[White Rock, British Columbia]] gets its name from a coastal erratic the size of a garage found on the beach at [[Semiahmoo Bay]], right at the [[border]] with [[Washington (state)|Washington]]. * The [[Foothills Erratics Train]] is a deposit of rocks of many sizes. These deposits stretch in a narrow belt for about {{convert|600|km|mi}} from Alberta's [[Athabasca River]] Valley to the southwest of the [[Provinces of Canada|province]]. * [[Doane Rock]], the largest exposed boulder in [[Cape Cod]]. * [[Madison Boulder]], a {{convert|5000|ST|MT|adj=on}} glacial erratic the size of a large house in [[Madison, New Hampshire]]. * Glen Rock, a boulder, weighing in at 570 short tons (520 t) in [[Glen Rock, New Jersey]], believed to have been carried to the site by a glacier that picked up the rock 15,000 years ago near Peekskill, New York. * The northern portion of the town of [[Waterville, Washington]] has a large number of large basalt erratics, particularly along the moraine running east-west from McNeil Canyon. * The [[Norber erratics]] in the [[Yorkshire Dales]] are one of [[England]]'s finest sets of glacial erratics. * The [[Great Stone of Fourstones]] at the county border between [[North Yorkshire]] and [[Lancashire]], [[England]]. * The Merton Stone, [[Merton, Norfolk|Merton]], [[Norfolk]], [[England]]. * [[Rollstone Boulder]], a 110-ton [[Granite|porphyritic granite]] boulder that was originally located at the summit of [[Rollstone Hill]] in [[Fitchburg, Massachusetts]]. It was carried by the last glaciation from [[Mount Monadnock]] in [[New Hampshire]]. Threatened by quarrying operations, it was moved to Litchfield Park in downtown Fitchburg in 1929-1930. * Ehalkivi (Sunset Glow Boulder) near [[Letipea]] in [[Estonia]], largest erratic boulder in the glaciation area of North Europe. Height 7m, circumference 48,2m, a volume of 930m3 and a mass of approx 2500 tonnes. * [[Puntukas]], one of national symbols of [[Lithuania]], near [[Anykščiai]] city. *Crosby Erratic, Coronation Park, [[Liverpool]], unearthed in field nearby in 1898<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/1125463|title= Glacial erratic - Coronation Park, Crosby|publisher=Geograph UK}}</ref> *[[Der Alte Schwede]], found in 1999, oldest in Germany. Further examples include the [[Giebichenstein]] and the [[Colossus of Ostermunzel]]. *The [[Clonfinlough Stone]], located in central Ireland, is covered with Bronze Age and medieval carvings. *[[Cloughmore]], near [[Rostrevor]] in [[County Down]], [[Northern Ireland]], is a glacial erratic found on the mountain high above the village. Located on the slopes of [[Slieve Martin]] the stone overlooks [[Carlingford Lough]] and the [[Cooley peninsula]]. *[[Lostenen]], located in western Finland *[[Soulbury Stone]], located in [[Soulbury]], [[Buckinghamshire]], England <ref>{{cite news |title=Soulbury stone: White lines 'horrific' and 'an eyesore' |work=BBC |date=16 April 2016 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-beds-bucks-herts-36024009}}</ref>
===Flood-borne erratics=== In the event that glacial ice is "rafted" by a flood such as that created when the ice dam broke during the [[Missoula Floods]], the erratics are deposited where the ice finally releases its debris load. One of the more unusual examples is found far from its origin in Idaho at [[Erratic Rock State Natural Site]] just outside [[McMinnville, Oregon]]. The park includes a {{convert|40|ST|MT|adj=on}} specimen, the largest erratic found in the [[Willamette Valley]].
==See also== {{Commons|Glacial erratic}} *[[Glacial erratic boulders of the Puget Sound region]] *[[Grannie stone]] *[[Jasper conglomerate]] *[[Precarious boulder]] *[[Sunday Rock]] *[[Willamette Meteorite]]
==References== {{reflist|2}} * Imbrie, J. & K. P. Imbrie. ''Ice Ages'', Enslow Publishers, Hillside, New Jersey, 1979.
==External links== {{Commonscat-inline|Glacial erratics}} * [http://www.royalalbertamuseum.ca/research/earthSciences/geology/erratic.cfm Royal Alberta Museum]
{{Continental Glaciations}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Glacial Erratic}} [[Category:Glacial erratics| ]]

revision.text:
[[File:Гривна (древнерусская).jpg|thumb|Round grivna (about {{convert|200|g|lb|abbr=on}})]] [[File:Grivna.jpg|thumb|Triangular Novgorod grivnas excavated near [[Koporye]]]] [[File:Hryvnia.png|thumb|100px|Kievan rhombic grivna]] [[File:Grivny.jpg|thumb|A hoard of rhombic Kievan grivnas at Moscow State Historical Museum]]
{{for|a Polish unit of weight|Grzywna (unit)}} '''Grivna''' was a currency as well as a measure of weight used in [[Kievan Rus']] and other East Slavic countries since the 11th century.<ref name=Langer/>
== Name == The word ''grivna'' is derived from {{proto|slavic|grivĭna|necklace}} from {{proto|slavic|griva|neck, nape, mane}}.<ref>{{ref-ru}} {{cite book|title=Etimilogicheskiy slovar' slavyanskikh yazykov|script-title=Этимологический словарь славянских языков|editor-first=Oleg|editor-last= Trubachyov|date=1980|place=Moscow|volume=7|pages=129–132}}</ref> In Old East Slavic it had the form {{lang|orv|гривьна}} ''grivĭna''. In modern East Slavic languages it has such forms: {{lang-ru|гри́вна}} ''grivna'', {{lang-uk|гри́вня}} ''hryvnia'', {{lang-be|гры́ўня}} ''hryŭnia''.
The name of the contemporary currency of Ukraine, ''[[hryvnia]]'', is derived from the ancient grivna.
== History ==
=== Early period === As its etymology implies the word originally meant a necklace or a torque, however the reason why it has taken the meaning of a unit of weight is unclear. The grivnas that have been found at various archaeological sites are not necklaces but [[bullion]]s of precious metals, usually silver. The weight and the shape of grivnas were not uniform, but varied by region. The grivnas of Novgorod and Pskov were thin long round-edged or three-edged ingots, while Kievan grivnas has rather the shape of a prolonged rhombus. The material was either gold or silver, but silver was predominant.<ref name=Riha/> Originally the weight of a grivna was close to the Roman or Byzantine [[pound (mass)|pound]]. The weight of the Kievan grivna was around {{convert|140-165|g|lb|abbr=on}}. The Novgorod grivna had the weight {{convert|204|g|lb}} and became the basis for monetary systems of North-Eastern Russian principalities and the emerging Russian state.<ref name=SlovarGrivna/>
Along the "grivna of silver" there were the account "grivna of kuna". The latter originally signified a certain amount of marten furs (''kuna'' is the word for marten in slavic languages). Since the 12th century the "grivna of kuna" became another unit of weight, but smaller, and signified as well a certain amount of silver coins: 2.5-gram ''nogata'' (from {{lang-ar|نقد}} ''naqd'' 'money; a coin') and ''rezan'' ({{frac|1|2}} [[dirham]]).<ref name=SlovarKuna/>
:1 grivna of silver (204 g) = 4 grivnas of kuna (51 g) = 80 nogata coins = 100 kunas (marten furs) = 200 rezans = 400–600 vekshas (squirrel furs)
=== Later period === Since the 14th century, when coins started to be minted in North-Eastern Rus (firstly in Moscow), the currency system of silver bullions and furs was becoming obsolete. The grivna became to mean not a weight but rather a partucular number of silver coins called then ''denga''. At the same time as early as the 13th century the word ruble (''rubl''') started to be used alongside the word grivna to mean a certain amount of either silver or silver coins. Thus one account ruble was equal to 216 denga coins (each weighted about 0.8 gram). The ''grivna of kuna'' became simply grivna and was equal to 14 dengas. Thus one ruble was equal to 15 new grivnas and 6 denga coins.
The weight of a denga coin in Moscow and Novgorod was different. In the 15th century the Moscow denga fell as low as 0.4 gram, while the Novgorod denga remained the same. When in Moscow one ruble had been revalued to 200 denga coins, the exchange rate between Moscow and Novgorod denga coins was set to 2 to 1. Thus since the later 15th – the early 16th centuries one account ruble was equal to 100 Novgorod dengas (later known as ''kopeks'') or to 200 Moscow dengas. In this system one grivna was equal to 10 kopeks or 20 dengas.
This last meaning survived into the 18th–20th centuries when one '''grivennik''' or '''grivenka''' meant a 10-kopek coin.
== Weight == The grivna as a silver bullion currency did not survive, but its meaning as a unit of weight became predominant. In 15th–17th centuries there were two weight grivnas (or ''grivenkas''): the "'''lesser grivna'''" of {{convert|204.756|g|ozt|abbr=on}} and the "'''greater grivna'''" of {{convert|409.512|g|ozt|abbr=on}}. Since the middle of the 17th century the latter became known as the Russian pound (Фунт, ''funt''). 40 Russian pounds or 80 lesser grivnas (grivenkas) are equal to one [[pood]].
== See also == * [[Obsolete Russian units of measurement]] * [[Manilla (money)|Manilla]]
== References == <references> <ref name=Langer>{{cite book|last1=Langer|first1=Lawrence N.|title=Historical Dictionary of Medieval Russia|date=2002|publisher=Scarecrow Press|pages=56–57|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DlWPEH3dF38C&pg=PA56|chapter=Grivna}}</ref> <ref name=Riha>{{cite book|last1=Riha|first1=Thomas|title=Readings in Russian Civilization|date=1969|publisher=The University of Chicago Press|volume=1|pages=23–24|edition=2nd|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_Bkddxc600IC&pg=PA23}}</ref> <ref name=SlovarGrivna>{{ref-ru}} {{cite book|title=Numizmatichesky Slovar'|script-title=Нумизматический словарь|editor=Zvarich V. V|place=Lvov|date=1980|chapter=Grivna|chapter-url=http://www.numizm.ru/html/g/grivna.html}}</ref> <ref name=SlovarKuna>{{ref-ru}} {{cite book|title=Numizmatichesky Slovar'|script-title=Нумизматический словарь|editor=Zvarich V. V|place=Lvov|date=1980|chapter=Kuna|chapter-url=http://www.numizm.ru/html/k/kuna.html}}</ref> </references>
== Further reading == * {{cite book|last1=Spassky|first1=Ivan|title=The Russian Monetary System: A Historico-numismatic Survey|date=1969|publisher=Argonaut}} * {{ref-ru}} {{cite book|last1=Kamentseva |first1=E.|last2=Ustyugov|first2=N.|title=Russkaya metrologiya|script-title=Русская метрология|date=1975}}

revision.comment: Adding [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "Lubrication measurement" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|Lubrication measurement}} [[File:HFRR_en.svg|alt=|thumb|princible of the HFRR measurement]] '''HFRR''' is a measurement for lubrication of [[Diesel fuel|Diesel]] or [[heating oil]] and stands for '''h'''igh '''f'''requency '''r'''eciprocating '''r'''ig. The value is given in [[Micrometre|µm]], lower is better. The measured value is the diameter of the flattening of the ball after the test.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sugiyama|first=Kouseki|last2=Kajiwara|first2=Masataka|last3=Fukumoto|first3=Masahiro|last4=Mori|first4=Makihiko|last5=Goto|first5=Shinichi|last6=Watanabe|first6=Tomoko|date=2004-06-08|title=Lubricity of Liquefied Gas Assessment of Multi-Pressure/Temperature High-Frequency Reciprocating Rig (MPT-HFRR) -DME Fuel for Diesel|url=http://papers.sae.org/2004-01-1865/|journal=SAE Technical Paper Series|volume=1|language=English|doi=10.4271/2004-01-1865}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|date=2010-01-01|title=Characterization of the lubricity of bio-oil/diesel fuel blends by high frequency reciprocating test rig|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S036054420900406X|journal=Energy|language=en|volume=35|issue=1|pages=283–287|doi=10.1016/j.energy.2009.09.020|issn=0360-5442|last1=Xu|first1=Yufu|last2=Wang|first2=Qiongjie|last3=Hu|first3=Xianguo|last4=Li|first4=Chuan|last5=Zhu|first5=Xifeng}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.astm.org/Standards/D6079|title=ASTM D6079 - 11(2016) Standard Test Method for Evaluating Lubricity of Diesel Fuels by the High-Frequency Reciprocating Rig (HFRR)|website=www.astm.org|access-date=2018-08-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.infineuminsight.com/insight/dec-2013/testing-the-test|title=HFRR best test for lubricity|website=www.infineuminsight.com|language=en|access-date=2018-08-08}}</ref>
It's important because high pressure [[Injection pump|injection pumps]] are only lubricated by the fuel itself. [[Density]] and [[viscosity]] are not sufficient describing the aptitude of the fuel.
== Examples of values ==
* [[biodiesel]] (Europe, Norm [[European Norm|EN]] 14214): ca. 320 µm * [[Diesel fuel|diesel]] (Europe, Norm [[DIN]] EN 590): < 460 µm * [[heating oil]] EL low sulfur (Germany, Norm [[DIN]] 51603-1): < 460 µm * Diesel (USA, Norm [[ASTM]]-D975): 550 - 600 µm<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.astm.org/Standards/D975.htm|title=ASTM D975 - 18 Standard Specification for Diesel Fuel Oils|website=www.astm.org|access-date=2018-08-08}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Fuels]] [[Category:Lubrication]] [[Category:Lubrication]]

The '''Handcar Regatta''', aka The Great West End and Railroad Square Handcar Regatta and Exposition of Mechanical and Artistic Wonders, is a popular [[handcar]] race and arts festival that is held in [[Santa Rosa, CA]]. It originated in 2008 and is held annually.<ref>[http://www.pressdemocrat.com/article/20120409/ARTICLES/120409576]</ref>
==History== Initial funding for the Handcar Regatta in 2008 came from the Santa Rosa [[Arts District]].
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Festivals in the San Francisco Bay Area]] [[Category:Culture of Santa Rosa, California]] [[Category:Human-powered vehicles]] [[Category:2000s in California]]

revision.text:
'''John Hamilton Adams''' (born 1936) is the founding director and trustee of the [[Natural Resources Defense Council]], founded in 1970. Adams served as executive director and, later, as president of the [[nonprofit]] conservation group until 2006.<ref>[http://www.nrdc.org/media/pressreleases/050310.asp John Adams, Leading Force for American Environment, Will Pass the Torch in 2006], press release, NRDC, March 10, 2005</ref> Prior to co-founding NRDC, Adams served as an assistant U.S. attorney in Manhattan. He also served as an adjunct faculty member at [[New York University|New York University's]] law school.
Adams graduated from [[Michigan State University]] and earned a law degree from [[Duke University]] in 1962.<ref>[http://www.nrdc.org/about/jha.asp John H. Adams, NRDC Founding Director], NRDC</ref> He was awarded the [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]] in 2011.<ref>http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/41604789/ns/politics-white_house/</ref><ref>[http://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2010/11/17/announcing-2010-medal-freedom-recipients Announcing The 2010 Medal of Freedom Recipients], whitehouse.gov, November 17, 2010] November 17, 2010.</ref>
Adams is currently chair of the board of the [[Open Space Institute]] and sits on the boards of numerous other environmental organizations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.osiny.org/site/PageServer?pagename=AboutOSI_Board|title=About|website=Open Space Institute}}</ref>
==Works== *Robert Cahn; John H Adams; et al., ''An Environmental agenda for the future'', [[Island Press]] (Washington, DC), 1985, {{ISBN|978-0-933280-29-8}}, OCLC 12557563 *John H. Adams and Patricia Adams with George Black, ''A Force for Nature'', [[Chronicle Books]] (San Francisco), August 2010, {{ISBN|978-0-8118-6535-7}}, OCLC 531718647
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.nrdc.org/about/jha.asp Profile] at [[Natural Resources Defense Council]] *{{C-SPAN|johnadams02}} *{{Worldcat id|lccn-n85-176500|John H. Adams}} *[http://www.sourcewatch.org/index.php?title=John_H._Adams John H. Adams] at [[SourceWatch]] *[http://www.chroniclebooks.com/index/main,book-info/store,books/products_id,8926/title,A-Force-for-Nature/ A Force for Nature] at [[Chronicle Books]] (publisher)
{{DEFAULTSORT:Adams, John H.}} [[Category:1936 births]] [[Category:Duke University School of Law alumni]] [[Category:Michigan State University alumni]] [[Category:Presidential Medal of Freedom recipients]] [[Category:American environmentalists]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Natural Resources Defense Council people]]

revision.text:
{{update|2013 is past|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox dam | name = Kandadji Dam | image = | image_caption = | name_official = | dam_crosses = [[Niger River]] | res_name = | location = [[Tillabéri Department]], [[Niger]] | operator = Haut Commissariat à l'Aménagement de la Vallée du Niger (High Commission for Niger Valley) | dam_length = {{convert|8780|m|yd}}<ref name=ESIA>{{cite web|title=Programme Kandadji de Régénération des Écosystèmes et de Mise en valeur de la vallée du Niger. Detailed Environmental and Social Impact Assessment|url=http://www.dialoguebarrages.org/dialoguebarrages/images/stories/downloads/Kandadji_General_Synthesis_Report.pdf|publisher=Tecsult Limited|accessdate=29 April 2013|pages=5|year=November 2006}}</ref> | dam_height = {{convert|28|m|abbr=on}}<ref name=ESIA/> | dam_width_base = | dam_width_crest = | dam_volume = | spillway_type = | spillway_capacity = {{convert|3150|m3|abbr=on}}<ref name=ESIA/> | construction_began = 2011 | opening = 2020 (estimated) <ref name=apa2018/> | cost = | res_capacity_total = {{convert|1596000|ML|acre.ft}}<ref name=ESIA/> | res_catchment = | res_surface = {{convert|282|km2|abbr=on}}<ref name=ESIA/> | res_max_depth = {{convert|5.67|m|abbr=on}}<ref name=ESIA/> | plant_operator = | plant_turbines = 4 | plant_capacity = {{convert|130|MW|abbr=on}} | plant_annual_gen = | plant_commission = | plant_decommission = | location_map = Niger | coordinates = {{coord|14.5900|1.0833|region:NE-6_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} }}
The '''Kandadji Dam''', when completed, will be a large multipurpose dam on the [[Niger River]]. The site is situated near the small town of [[Kandadji]], [[Tillabéri Department]], [[Tillabéri Region]], [[Niger]], 180 km northwest of the capital [[Niamey]].<ref>[http://www.fallingrain.com/world/NG/9/Kandadji.html Kandadji, Niger Page]. Falling Rain.com. Retrieved 2009-02-01</ref> Construction of the dam was begun in August 2008.<ref>[http://appablog.wordpress.com/2008/10/10/niger-afd-bank-group-president-receives-niger%E2%80%99s-finance-and-economy-minister/ Niger / AfD Bank Group President receives Niger’s Finance and Economy Minister]. African Press Organization (APO). October 10, 2008/</ref> It is being built by the ''Haut Commissariat à l'Aménagement de la Vallée du Niger'' (High Commission for Niger Valley), a public body under the Primer Minister's Office. The dam will generate hydropower and is aimed at controlling the flow of the Niger River, holding water during the dry season to maintain a minimum flow and making downstream irrigation possible. The project is formally named the ''Kandadji Programme for Ecosystem Regeneration and Niger River Development'' (''Programme Kandadji de Régénération des Ecosystèmes et de Mise en Valeur du Fleuve Niger''). In 2008<ref name="Reuters">ReutersAlertNet:[http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L4302162.htm Niger begins building dam for food, electricity], 4 August 2008</ref> the dam itself was expected to be completed in 2013. By 2012<ref>{{cite web|title=Niger Criticizes Russian Company Over Delays on Hydropower Dam|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-03-02/niger-criticizes-russian-company-over-delays-on-hydropower-dam.html|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=29 April 2013|date=2 March 2012}}</ref> the completion date had moved to September 2015. Construction has been slower than expected, with interruptions due to financing problems; as of 2018, completion is expected in 2020.<ref name=apa2018>{{cite web|url=http://mobile.apanews.net/en/news/president-issoufou-wants-more-infrastructure-in-niger|title=President Issoufou wants more infrastructure in Niger|date=1 January 2018}}</ref>
The project is a very high-profile project for Niger. According to the Prime Minister at the time of initiating construction, [[Seyni Oumarou]], "no other development project will have sparked so much long term interest or such high expectations". The first brick of the dam was laid by the President of Niger, [[Mamadou Tandja]].<ref name="Reuters"/>
== History == The project was first proposed in the 1970s, when a larger dam had been considered. In 1998 the African Development Bank approved funding for a feasibility study that was conducted by the German consulting firm Lahmeyer. Under the study, an environmental and social diagnosis and an initial environmental and social assessment were conducted. The findings were presented in 2002. In August 2002 the government decided by Decree to go ahead with the project, which was from that time called the Kandadji Ecosystems Regeneration and Niger Valley Development Programme. Subsequently, a detailed assessment of environmental and social impact, including a Population Resettlement Plan and a Local Development Plan, was conducted. The Local Development Plan was designed to facilitate the economic transition of displaced persons in order to restore their standard of living or even enhance it, beyond mere resettlement. The final design of the dam was prepared with financing from the [[Islamic Development Bank]], and that of a {{convert|2000|ha}} irrigation project with financing from the [[West African Development Bank]].<ref>Republic of Niger, Prime Minister’s Office, High Commission for Niger Valley / African Development Bank:[http://www.afdb.org/fileadmin/uploads/afdb/Documents/Environmental-and-Social-Assessments/ADF-BD-IF-2008-51-EN-NIGER-KANDADJI-ECOSYSTEMS-REGENERATION-DETAILED-POPULATION-RESETTLEMENT-PLAN.PDF "KANDADJI" ECOSYSTEMS REGENERATION AND NIGER VALLEY DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMME (KERNVDP), DETAILED POPULATION RESETTLEMENT PLAN], EXECUTIVE SUMMARY, February 2008, p. 1-2</ref> In 2005 and 2006 consultations were undertaken as part of the environmental and social assessment, which included participants from the [[World Wide Fund for Nature]] and [[International Union for Conservation of Nature]].<ref>Republic of Niger, Prime Minister’s Office, High Commission for Niger Valley / African Development Bank:[http://www.afdb.org/fileadmin/uploads/afdb/Documents/Environmental-and-Social-Assessments/ADF-BD-IF-2008-50-EN-NIGER-ESIA-KANDADJI-ECOSYSTEMS-REGENERATION-AND-NIGER-VALLEY-DEVELOPMENT-PROGRAMME.PDF "KANDADJI" ECOSYSTEMS REGENERATION AND NIGER VALLEY DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMME (KERNVDP), DETAILED ENVIRONMENTAL AND SOCIAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT, EXECUTIVE SUMMARY], January 2008, p. 12</ref> According to one source, construction of the dam was begun in August 2008. In April 2009 a workshop on benefit sharing from dams in West Africa was held in Niamey organized by the [[Niger Basin Authority]], the [[International Institute for Environment and Development]] and the [[International Union for Conservation of Nature]]. The workshop recommended to improve the communication towards the people affected by the dam and to pay particular attention to legal processes related to resettlement, and to continue to reflect on a future management structure to equitably share the benefits of the dam.<ref>[[IUCN]]:[http://www.iucn.org/fr/propos/union/secretariat/bureaux/paco/programmes/peauzh/?3138/Les-acteurs-echangent-sur-le-partage-des-benefices-et-la-gestion-des-reservoirs Les acteurs échangent sur le partage des bénéfices et la gestion des réservoirs], 6 May 2009</ref> In November 2009 a process to select consultants to accompany the resettlement has been initiated.<ref>[http://www.hydroworld.com/index/display/article-display.articles.hrhrw.tendersandnotices.tenders.2009.11.niger-seeks_relocation.QP129867.dcmp=rss.page=1.html Niger seeks relocation consultants for 125-MW Kandadji], 20 November 2009</ref>
According to the World Bank, the entire Kandadji Program will be implemented in three phases: * Phase I, which started in 2009 and is expected to be completed in 2016, comprises the Kandadji dam and its reservoir, the hydro-mechanical equipment for the 18 gates, economic and local community development, and implementation of environmental and social mitigation measures for resettled people; * Phase II comprises construction of the hydropower plant, transmission lines, road, irrigated agricultural development, and expanded local and community development in the reservoir area and downstream, and * Phase III focuses on the development of irrigated agriculture and the scaling-up of the economy and local community development of the region (including fisheries, livestock, agribusiness and trade.<ref name="World Bank Fact Sheet">{{cite web|title=The Kandadji Program in the Sahel|url=http://siteresources.worldbank.org/INTAFRICA/Resources/257994-1349215552505/niger-kandadji-program-boost-regional-economic-growth-agriculture-electricity-sahel-fact-sheet.pdf|publisher=World Bank|accessdate=29 April 2013}}</ref>
Construction of the dam itself was contracted to Russian company [[Zarubezhvodstroy]], which signed the construction contract in September 2010.<ref name=Zarubezhvodstroy/> Construction of the dam was relaunched at a ceremony on 23 May 2011, following the election of President [[Mahamadou Issoufou]].<ref>[http://www.africanmanager.com/articles/133576.html Le président du Niger lance la construction d’un barrage hydro-électrique]. PANA Press, 2011-05-24</ref><ref name="sg.news.yahoo.com">[http://sg.news.yahoo.com/russian-firm-starts-niger-hydro-dam-113900578.html Russian firm starts work on Niger hydro dam]. Abdoulaye Massalatchi Reuters – Tue, May 24, 2011</ref><ref>[http://coddae.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=50:presentation-du-barrage-de-kandadji&catid=32:dossiers&Itemid=41 Présentation du Barrage de Kandadji]</ref><ref>[http://www.africaintelligence.com/C/modules/login/DetailArt/LoginDetailArt.asp?rub=login&lang=ANG&service=ART&context=PUS&doc_i_id=90553746&NoAboPme=1 NIGER - Kandadji a free pass for Moscow - Africa Energy Intelligence]</ref> The Kandaji Dam is the first object being constructed by a Russian company in Niger.<ref name="Kandaji Dam: History">{{cite web| url= http://www.zvs.ru/en/about/news/|title=Kandaji Dam: History|publisher=Zarubezhvodstroy» OJSC |accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref> In May 2011, the Director General of Zarubezhvodstroy, OJSC E.V. Gudzenchuk, announced "For the first time a Russian company is involved in building such a large project in West Africa at the expense of foreign investors. Zarubezhvodstroy has vast experience in the field that would allow us to meet the challenges with confidence and with great professionalism."<ref name="Kandaji Dam: History"/>
Plans were announced in June 2011 to relocate 5383 individuals and 770 families who will be displaced by the dam.<ref>[http://www.afriquinfos.com/articles/2011/6/23/niger-180771.asp Les riverains du barrage de Kandadji seront déplacés et indemnisés - Afriquinfos]</ref>
== Technical features == The earth dyke dam will be 8.4 km dam long, creating a reservoir of 1.6 billion m<sup>3</sup> and a regulated discharge of 120 m<sup>3</sup>/s (3.8 km<sup>3</sup>/year) in Niamey. The hydroelectric plant will have a capacity of 130 megawatt, and a 132 kilovolt high voltage line will be built over 188 km to Niamey. Irrigation development will consist of a first phase of 6,000 hectares mainly for the benefit of resettled communities, with a medium-term target in 2034 of 45,000 hectares out of an irrigable potential of 122,000 hectares.<ref>Republic of Niger, Prime Minister’s Office, High Commission for Niger Valley / African Development Bank:[http://www.afdb.org/fileadmin/uploads/afdb/Documents/Environmental-and-Social-Assessments/ADF-BD-IF-2008-51-EN-NIGER-KANDADJI-ECOSYSTEMS-REGENERATION-DETAILED-POPULATION-RESETTLEMENT-PLAN.PDF "KANDADJI" ECOSYSTEMS REGENERATION AND NIGER VALLEY DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMME (KERNVDP), DETAILED POPULATION RESETTLEMENT PLAN], EXECUTIVE SUMMARY, February 2008, p. 3-4</ref>
== Benefits == The expected benefits include increased agricultural production and hydropower generation. Niger imports almost half of its electricity consumption of {{convert|440|e6kWh}} (2007) from neighboring Nigeria, which itself suffers frequent power cuts. The plant would increase installed capacity in Niger from 240 [[Megawatt]] (MW) in 2007 to 370 MW (+55%).<ref>U.S. [[Energy Information Administration]]:http://tonto.eia.doe.gov/country/country_energy_data.cfm?fips=NG Niger Energy Profile, accessed on January 10, 2009</ref> Other expected benefits are related to "drinking water supply, sanitation, improved flood recession cropping, grazing and fishery".<ref name="Saudi">AfricanManager:[http://www.africanmanager.com/site_eng/detail_article.php?art_id=12796 Saudi Fund grants US$20 million to Niger for Kandadji dam], 9 January 2010</ref>
== Financial costs == The financial costs of the broader project, including the infrastructure for irrigation and drinking water supply, were estimated at US$670 million by one source in 2007.<ref>Reuters:[https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSL03684978 Niger says secures $236 mln Islamic funding for dam], 3 December 2007</ref> Another source mentions US$942 million in 2011.<ref name="sg.news.yahoo.com"/> The contract to build the dam itself, however, is apparently only worth Euro 130million.<ref name=Zarubezhvodstroy/> According to the World Bank, the Kandadji Program (Phase I and Phase II) is expected to cost US$785 million.<ref name="World Bank Fact Sheet"/>
== Financing == Financing comes from ten sources: the African Development Bank, the Islamic Development Bank, the West African Development Bank, the Saudi Fund for Development, the Kuwait Fund for Arab Economic Development, the OPEC Fund for International Development, the Arab Bank for Economic Development in Africa, the Bank for Investment and Development of the [[Economic Community of West African States]] (ECOWAS) and the Government of Niger.<ref name=Zarubezhvodstroy>{{cite web|title=News|url=http://www.zvs.ru/en/about/news/|publisher=Zarubezhvodstroy|accessdate=29 April 2013|date=23 May 2011}}</ref>
Specific amounts are as follows, as far as known: * US$236 million was pledged by the [[Islamic Development Bank]].<ref name="HydroWorld.com">{{cite web| url= http://www.hydroworld.com/articles/2008/11/african-bank-funds-nigers-125-mw-kandadji-dam-ecosystems.html|title=African bank funds Niger's 125-MW Kandadji Dam, ecosystems|publisher=HydroWorld.com|accessdate=July 19, 2012}}</ref> * US$15 million was pledged by the [[OPEC Fund for International Development]] in February 2009.<ref>OFID:[http://www.ofid.org/projects_operations/commitments_2008.aspx Commitments in 2008], accessed on January 9, 2010</ref> * US$62 million were approved in October 2008 by the [[African Development Bank]] through a combined loan and grant.<ref>African Development Bank:[http://www.afdb.org/en/news-events/article/niger-us-62-million-adf-funding-for-the-development-of-niger-valley-ecosystems-3398/ Niger: US$62 Million ADF Funding for the development of Niger Valley Ecosystems], 31 October 2008</ref> * US$20 million were approved in January 2010 by the [[Saudi foreign assistance|Saudi Development Fund]]. <ref name="Saudi"/> * US$200 million from the World Bank.<ref name="World Bank Fact Sheet"/>
Financing for the hydropower station itself is due to come from a public-private partnership.<ref name="Reuters"/><ref name="HydroWorld.com"/>
== Environmental, social and downstream impact == Negative social impacts include the resettlement of almost 35,000 people from 15 villages, loss of infrastructure (a national road, boreholes, clinics, schools, mosques, slaughterhouses, markets and grain mills) and loss of about 7,000 ha of agricultural land. According to a 2007 report by [[UNEP]]'s Dams and Development Project, which itself was a follow-up activity to a report by the [[World Commission on Dams]], the Kandadji project "serves as a useful example of the projection and estimation of social effects, which appears to have been widely encompassing, covering both negative impacts and benefits". These impacts were "projected at an early stage in project planning, enabling issues and potential impacts to be addressed in subsequent planning phases".<ref>[[UNEP]]:[http://www.unep.org/dams/files/Compendium/Report_SIA.pdf DAMS AND DEVELOPMENT PROJECT, COMPENDIUM ON RELEVANT PRACTICES, Social Impact Assessment of Affected People], Final Report, August 2007, p. x, accessed on January 10, 2009</ref>
The project is expected to improve the river's ecology, which has suffered from a 30% decline in river flows since the 1970s.<ref>Republic of Niger, Prime Minister’s Office, High Commission for Niger Valley / African Development Bank:[http://www.afdb.org/fileadmin/uploads/afdb/Documents/Environmental-and-Social-Assessments/ADF-BD-IF-2008-51-EN-NIGER-KANDADJI-ECOSYSTEMS-REGENERATION-DETAILED-POPULATION-RESETTLEMENT-PLAN.PDF "KANDADJI" ECOSYSTEMS REGENERATION AND NIGER VALLEY DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMME (KERNVDP), DETAILED POPULATION RESETTLEMENT PLAN], EXECUTIVE SUMMARY, February 2008, p. 2</ref> The dam would regulate flows. According to press reports from Nigeria, the project would reduce the river flow to Nigeria by at least 10 percent, thus jeopardizing power production from two existing dams in Nigeria and meaning a "colossal loss (...) to the agricultural capacity of (Nigerian) states that border the River Niger".<ref>BusinessdayOnline:[http://www.businessdayonline.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2276:new-dam-on-river-niger-why-it-is-crucial-nigeria-responds-&catid=117:news&Itemid=298 New dam on River Niger: Why it is crucial Nigeria responds], 8 January 2009, by Martin Ayankola</ref> However, according to the 2008 environmental assessment of the project, the "modifications of the quantities of water flowing into the Niger River as a result of the Kandadji dam will be minimal in Nigeria". The average loss through evaporation and modification of the Niger River water flows in Nigeria will be low (2.3% at Jebba) and there will be positive impacts by improving the minimum water level in Nigeria.<ref>Republic of Niger, Prime Minister’s Office, High Commission for Niger Valley / African Development Bank:[http://www.afdb.org/fileadmin/uploads/afdb/Documents/Environmental-and-Social-Assessments/ADF-BD-IF-2008-50-EN-NIGER-ESIA-KANDADJI-ECOSYSTEMS-REGENERATION-AND-NIGER-VALLEY-DEVELOPMENT-PROGRAMME.PDF "KANDADJI" ECOSYSTEMS REGENERATION AND NIGER VALLEY DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMME (KERNVDP), DETAILED ENVIRONMENTAL AND SOCIAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT, EXECUTIVE SUMMARY], January 2008, p. 11</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|33em}}
== Further sources == *[http://www.lahmeyer.com/e/units/gw/kandadji.pdf Multi-purpose Projects: Kandadji Dam Niger]. Lahmeyer International (2008). (Link broken) *[http://www.ajeam-ragee.org/getdoc.asp?fpath=c:%5Cdomains%5Cajeam-ragee.org%5Cdb%5Cvol5april2003p46-54.doc Assessment of the environmental impacts of the Kandadji dam project: an energy choice identified under the National Energy and Sustainable Development Program]. Hassane Kimba / Nigerian Association of Environmental Impact Assessment Professionals. AJEAM-RAGEE Volume 5 April 2003; 46-54 (Link broken) *[http://aochycos.abn.ne/HTMLF/PARTNAT/BAR-KAND/ Haut Commissariat au Barrage de Kandadji (official site)]. Republique du Niger: Cabinet du Premier Ministre. Retrieved 2009-02-01. (Link broken) *Niger - Evaluation de l'effet du barrage de Kandadji sur les pêcheries du fleuve Niger. Un rapport préparé pour le projet assistance a l'Autorité du Barrage de Kandadji (ABK); Document de travail 1. (French) Welcomme, R.L., / FAO, Rome (Italy). Fisheries Dept., 1981, 7 p. Report No: FAO-FI—TCP/NER/0103(MA) * Jamie Skinner:[http://www.iied.org/niger-tough-questions-posed-kandadji-dam-development Niger: Tough questions posed by the Kandadji dam development], International Institute for Environment and Development, 19 April 2013
{{stack|{{Portal|Niger|Water|Renewable energy}}}}
