page.title: List of boiler types, by manufacturer

revision.text:
There have been a vast number of designs of [[steam boiler]], particularly towards the end of the 19th century when the technology was evolving rapidly. A great many of these took the names of their originators or primary manufacturers, rather than a more descriptive name. Some large manufacturers also made boilers of several types. Accordingly, it is difficult to identify their technical aspects from merely their name. This list presents these known, notable names and a brief description of their main characteristics. == See also == * [[Glossary of boiler terminology]] {{compact ToC|side=yes|top=yes|num=no}} == A == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Definitions ! Points of Interest |- |width="895"| * '''[[Admiralty three-drum boiler]]'''{{anchor|Admiralty boiler}}: the [[Royal Navy]]'s standardised pattern of [[#three-drum boiler|three-drum boiler]]. * '''annular fire-tube boiler''': a vertical [[fire-tube boiler]] with the tubes arranged radially,{{sfn|Harris, Model Boilers|pages=56–57}} such as the [[#Robertson boiler|Robertson]]. * '''annular water-tube boiler''':{{anchor|annular water-tube boiler}} a vertical [[water-tube boiler]] with the tubes arranged radially, such as the [[#Straker boiler|Straker]] with horizontal tubes, or near-vertically and conically{{sfn|Harris, Model Boilers|page=55}} as used by [[Thornycroft]] for [[steam wagon]]s. * '''{{Visible anchor|auxiliary boiler}}''': An ''auxiliary'' boiler, on a [[steam ship]], supplies steam that is not used for main propulsion, but is necessary for some part of the essential machinery.{{cite book |title=Marine Steam Boilers |last=Milton |first=J. H. |publisher=Newnes |edition=2nd |origyear=1953 |year=1961 |page=60 |ref={{harvid|Milton, Marine Steam Boilers}} }}
See also [[#donkey boiler|donkey boiler]].
A small boiler may be used as an auxiliary boiler when at sea, or a donkey boiler in port. A ''composite auxiliary boiler'' does this, using waste heat from the main engines when at sea, or is separately fired when acting as a donkey boiler. Auxiliary boilers were also present in some locomotives, in particular those used in passenger rail service, where steam was used as heating for the cars being pulled. With the advent of [[head end power]], these steam boilers were phased out, often being replaced with concrete weights. | [[File:Thornycroft vertical water-tube boiler, section (Rankin Kennedy, Modern Engines, Vol III).jpg|center|thumb|180px|Thornycroft steam wagon boiler, an [[#annular water-tube boiler|annular water-tube]] with inclined tubes]] |} == B == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Definitions ! Points of Interest |- |width="895"| * '''Babcock-Johnson boiler''': early production [[#Johnson boiler|Johnson boiler]]s operating at high pressures (850psi) and with [[Glossary of boiler terminology#Water-wall|water-wall]] ends to their furnace.{{sfn||Milton, Marine Steam Boilers|pages=111-115}} * '''[[Babcock & Wilcox boiler]]'''{{anchor|Babcock & Wilcox boiler}} * '''[[Babcock & Wilcox marine boiler]]''' * '''[[Bagnall boiler]]''': a development of the launch boiler, with an enlarged furnace. Also known in agricultural use as the 'colonial' or 'Britannia'. * '''[[Belleville boiler]]'''{{anchor|Belleville boiler}}: an early marine [[#water-tube boiler|water-tube boiler]] developed in France by [[Julien Belleville]].{{cite journal|author=Uri Zelbstein |title=L'histoire d'une invention: Julien Belleville et sa chaudière à tubes d'eau |date=1987 |journal=History and Technology, an International Journal |volume=3 |issue=2 |pages=205-218 |language=French |doi=10.1080/07341518708581667 }} {{cite book |title=The Naval Annual |last=Brassey |first=Thomas Allnutt |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wVuqxYUi3o4C&pg=PA118 |publisher=Brassey |year=1896 |isbn=1-4212-4178-1 |ref=Naval Annual (1896) |pages=118–119 }}{{Cite book |title=Warrior to Dreadnought |last=Brown |first=David K |origyear=1997 |year=2010 |publisher=Chatham |isbn=978-1-84832-086-4 |ref={{harvid|Brown|1997}} |page=137 }} * '''[[Benson boiler]]''': a [[#monotube boiler|monotube]] "once-through" [[steam generator (boiler)|steam generator]].{{sfn|Milton, Marine Steam Boilers|pages=144-145}} * '''[[Vertical boiler with horizontal fire-tubes#Blake boiler|Blake boiler]]''' * '''[[Blechynden boiler]]'''{{anchor|Blechynden boiler}}: An early naval [[#water-tube boiler|water-tube boiler]].{{sfnp|Brown|1997|page=140}} * '''[[Bolsover Express boiler]]''' {{cite book |title=Model Boilers and Boilermaking |last=Harris |first=K. N. |isbn=0-85242-377-2 |publisher=MAP |year=1974 |pages=58–59 |ref={{harvid|Harris, Model Boilers}} }} * '''[[box boiler]]'''{{anchor|box boiler}}: An early marine boiler with flat sides. Owing to the flat sides, even with extensive rod stays, the boilers were only suitable for low pressures. These boilers were physically large and contained a few large flues, each heated by its own furnace. The flues were round, rectangular or arched and usually long and labyrinthine.{{Cite book |title=The evolution of engineering in the Royal Navy |volume=Vol 1: 1827-1939 |last=Rippon |first=Commander P.M., RN |year=1998 |publisher=Spellmount |isbn=0-946771-55-3 |ref=harv |page=29 }} * '''[[Brotan boiler]]'''{{anchor|Brotan boiler}}: a rarely used boiler for steam locomotives that combined a conventional fire-tube boiler barrel with a water-tube firebox. There is a prominent steam drum above the boiler barrel, making it resemble a [[#Flaman boiler|Flaman boiler]].{{cite web |title=Brotan |url=http://www.douglas-self.com/MUSEUM/LOCOLOCO/brotan/brotan.htm |author=Douglas Self |authorlink=Douglas Self |publisher= Loco Locomotive gallery }}{{cite web |title=Brotan |url=http://erojr.home.cern.ch/erojr/Content/phylo/BROTAN.HTM }} ** '''[[Brotan boiler#Brotan-Deffner boiler|Brotan-Deffner boiler]]'''{{anchor|Brotan-Deffner boiler}}{{anchor|Brotan-Defner boiler}}: a variant of the [[#Brotan boiler|Brotan boiler]]. The steam drum was shortened and placed behind the boiler barrel, giving a much more conventional silhouette. Around a thousand of these were used in [[Hungarian State Railways|Hungary]]. ** '''[[Brotan boiler#Brotan-Fialovits boiler|Brotan-Fialovits boiler]]''': a further variant of the [[#Brotan-Deffner boiler|Brotan-Deffner boiler]]. * '''[[bundled-tube water-tube boiler]]'''{{anchor|bundled-tube water-tube boiler}}; early [[#large-tube water-tube boiler|large-tube water-tube boiler]]s where the tubes were grouped into bundles (of 19, for [[Centered hexagonal number|geometrical reasons]]) that shared a common header, so as to improve shared access for tube cleaning.{{sfn|Kennedy, Modern Engines, Vol VI|pages=}} * '''[[Flued boiler#Butterley boiler|Butterley boiler]]''': a form of [[#Cornish boiler|Cornish boiler]] where the furnace was opened up into a "whistle mouth", enlarging the grate area. | [[File:Babcock and Wilcox boiler (Heat Engines, 1913).jpg|center|thumb|180px|'''Babcock & Wilcox''']] [[File:Brotans boiler.jpg|center|thumb|180px|'''Brotan-Defner''' boiler firebox]] |} == C == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Definitions ! Points of Interest |- |width="895"| * '''[[Vertical cross-tube boiler|Clarke Chapman "Tyne" boiler]]''': a form of vertical water-tube boiler, a development of the [[#cross-tube boiler|cross-tube boiler]] intended to encourage better water circulation. * '''[[Vertical boiler with horizontal fire-tubes#Clarke Chapman boiler|Clarke Chapman "Victoria" boiler]]''': a form of vertical cross-fire-tube boiler. * '''[[Clarkson thimble tube boiler]]'''{{cite web |url=http://www.gracesguide.co.uk/Clarkson_Thimble_Tube_Boiler_Co |title=Clarkson Thimble Tube Boiler Co |website=Grace's Guide |accessdate=10 April 2018 }}{{anchor|thimble-tube boiler}}: the original thimble-tube boiler, using a great many short closed-ended watertubes. Often used for heat-recovery from the exhaust of large Diesel engines.{{sfn|Harris, Model Boilers|pages=58-60}} * '''[[Climax boiler]]''': A vertical water-tube boiler with many long spiral coils around a central steam-and-water drum.{{sfn|Kennedy, Modern Engines, Vol V|pages= }} * '''[[Cochran boiler]]''': a vertical boiler with horizontal fire-tubes.{{cite book |title=Marine Steam Boilers |last=Milton |first=J. H. |publisher=Newnes |edition=2nd |origyear=1953 |year=1961 |pages=63–66 |ref={{harvid|Milton, Marine Steam Boilers}} }} * '''[[composite boiler]]'''{{anchor|composite boiler}}: a boiler used for either direct-firing, or as a [[#heat-recovery boiler|heat-recovery boiler]].{{sfn|Milton, Marine Steam Boilers|pages=119–137}} * '''[[Corner tube boiler]]'''{{anchor|Cornertube boiler}}: a natural circulation water tube boiler in which the pre-separation of steam takes place from the water-steam mixture outside the drum and the preheated downcomers. * '''[[Cornish boiler]]'''{{anchor|Cornish boiler}}: a large horizontal stationary boiler with a single flue. * '''[[vertical cross-tube boiler|cross-tube boiler]]'''{{anchor|cross-tube boiler}}: usually a vertical flued boiler with a small number of large water-carrying cross-tubes within the firebox. : The term is also applied to vertical boilers with other arrangements of tubes, such as those with [[vertical boiler with horizontal fire-tubes|horizontal fire-tubes]]. * '''[[Crosti boiler]]'''{{anchor|Crosti boiler}}: | [[File:Cornish boiler, end-section (Heat Engines, 1913).jpg|center|thumb|180px|section through a [[#Cornish boiler|'''Cornish''' boiler]]]] [[File:Single flue vertical boiler (Heat Engines, 1913).jpg|center|thumb|180px|Vertical flue [[#cross-tube boiler|'''cross-tube''' boiler]]]] |} == D == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Definitions ! Points of Interest |- |width="895"| * '''[[De Poray boiler]]''': patented French designs with a secondary combustion chamber to improve combustion efficiency. A vertical form of this uses [[#field-tube boiler|field-tube]]s. * '''[[Doble steam-car boiler]]'''{{anchor|Doble|}}: * '''{{Visible anchor|donkey boiler}}''': A ''donkey'' boiler is used to supply non-essential steam to a ship for 'hotel' services such as heating or lighting when the main boilers are not in steam, for example, when in port. Donkey boilers were also used by the last sailing ships for working winches and anchor capstans.
See also [[#auxiliary boiler|auxiliary boiler]]. * '''[[du Temple boiler]]'''{{anchor|Du Temple boiler}}: An early naval [[#three-drum boiler|water-tube boiler]], patented in 1876.{{sfnp|Brown|1997|page=140}}{{cite book |title=970 Mechanical Appliances and Novelties of Construction |author=Gardner D. Hiscox |origyear=1904 |publisher=Algrove Publishing |year=2001 |isbn=1-894572-37-8 |pages=58 |ref=970 Mechanical Appliances }} * '''Dublin "economic" boiler''': a vertical multitubular return fire-tube design, for [[model engineering]]-scale uses.{{sfn|Harris, Model Boilers|pages=160–161}} * '''Dürr boiler''' An early naval water-tube boiler, developed and mostly used in Germany, but also trialled in the British {{HMS|Medusa|1888}}{{sfnp|Brown|1997|page=165}} |} == E == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Definitions ! Points of Interest |- |width="895"| * '''[[Early steam boilers#Egg-ended boiler|egg-ended boiler]]''':{{anchor|egg-ended boiler}} an early form of tubular [[#wagon boiler|wagon boiler]], with hemispherical ends to support higher pressures. * '''[[Early steam boilers#Elephant boiler|Elephant boiler]]''': an early multi-cylindered [[#wagon boiler|wagon boiler]], popular in France. * '''[[:Category:express boilers|express boiler]]''':{{anchor|express boiler}} another term for [[#small-tube water-tube boiler|small-tube water-tube boiler]]s, on account of their high ratio between heating surface area and water volume, and thus their rapid steam-raising. | [[File:Egg-ended and wagon boilers at Armley Mills by Chris Allen.jpg|center|thumb|180px|[[#egg-ended boiler|Egg-ended boiler]]
with ([[#wagon boiler|wagon]] boiler behind)]] |} == F == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Definitions ! Points of Interest |- |width="895"| * '''[[flued boiler#Fairbairn's five-tube boiler|Fairbairn's five-tube boiler]]''' * '''[[Fairbairn-Beeley boiler]]''', a fire-tube boiler with multiple joined shells of small diameter * '''Fairfield-Johnson boiler''': a later form of [[#Johnson boiler|Johnson boiler]] operating at lower pressure (450psi rather than 850psi), but still a high superheat temperature {{convert|825|°F|°C}}.{{sfn||Milton, Marine Steam Boilers|pages=111-115}} * '''[[Fairlie locomotive|Fairlie boiler]]'''{{anchor|Fairlie boiler}}: A double-ended locomotive boiler with a central firebox, used in Fairlie's patent for double-ended articulated steam locomotives. * '''[[field-tube boiler]]'''{{anchor|field-tube boiler}}:{{sfn|Harris, Model Boilers|pages=52–53}} * '''[[fire-tube boiler]]'''{{anchor|fire-tube boiler}}: A boiler with many narrow fire-tubes inside a water drum. A development of the [[#flued boiler|flued boiler]], where the many smaller tubes give a much larger heating surface area for the overall boiler volume. * '''[[Flaman boiler]]'''{{anchor|Flaman boiler}}: an attempt to squeeze the largest possible locomotive boiler into the [[loading gauge]] by splitting the boiler into two drums: a fire-tube boiler beneath and a steam drum above.{{cite web |title=Flaman |url=http://www.douglas-self.com/MUSEUM/LOCOLOCO/flaman/flaman.htm |publisher= Loco Locomotive gallery }} * '''[[flued boiler]]'''{{anchor|flued boiler}}: A boiler with only one or two large diameter fire-tubes inside a water drum. These later developed into the [[#fire-tube boiler|fire-tube boiler]]. * '''[[forced-circulation boiler]]'''{{anchor|forced-circulation boiler}}: boilers where circulation is forced by a pump, rather than relying on [[thermosyphon]] effect. These may use either forced-water-circulation (e.g. [[#La Mont boiler|La Mont]]) or forced-steam-circulation (e.g. [[#Löffler boiler|Löffler]]).{{sfn|Milton, Marine Steam Boilers|pages=138-145}} * '''[[Foster-Wheeler boiler]]''' {{anchor|Foster-Wheeler boiler}} ** '''[[Foster-Wheeler boiler#D type|D type]]''' ** '''[[Foster-Wheeler boiler#controlled-superheat|controlled-superheat type]]''' ** '''[[Foster-Wheeler boiler#ESD|ESD type]]''' (External Superheat, D type) * '''[[Franco-Crosti boiler]]'''{{anchor|Franco-Crosti boiler}}: | [[File:Chaudiere flaman.jpg|center|thumb|180px|[[#Flaman boiler|Flaman boiler]]]] |} == G == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Definitions ! Points of Interest |- |width="895"| * '''[[Lancashire boiler#Galloway boiler|Galloway boiler]]''': a [[#Lancashire boiler|Lancashire boiler]] fitted with [[Galloway tube]]s. Originally these fused the Lancashire boiler's original two flues into a single [[reniform|kidney-shaped]] flue, with the tubes mounted in the joined section. Later boilers kept the cylindrical flues separate and placed the tubes within them. * '''[[gothic boiler]]'''{{anchor|gothic boiler}}: an early [[#locomotive boiler|locomotive boiler]], where the outer firebox was particularly large and served as the [[Glossary of boiler terminology#Dome|steam dome]], often highly decorated with polished brass. These were popular for early railway locomotives, from 1830 to 1850.{{sfn|Hewison, Boiler Explosions|page=12}} : This is another form of boiler frequently described as a "[[#haystack boiler|haystack]]". * '''[[gunboat boiler]]'''{{anchor|gunboat boiler}}: similar to the commonly known locomotive boiler, from [[steam locomotive]]s.
A horizontal boiler drum contains multiple fire-tubes and a separate furnace. However, the furnace in a gunboat boiler has no opening at the bottom of the furnace to allow dumping of ash; the furnace is completely water-cooled, similar to a Scotch boiler furnace. These boilers were used in early torpedo boats and gunboats, having low height for protection from enemy gunfire. | [[File:Galloway tube in kidney flue, end-section.jpg|center|thumb|center|180px|'''Galloway boiler''']] |} == H == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Definitions ! Points of Interest |- |width="895"| * '''[[Vertical boiler with horizontal fire-tubes#Harris "Economic" boiler|Harris "Economic" boiler]]'''{{sfn|Harris, Model Boilers|pages=158–160}} * '''[[Early steam boilers#Haystack boiler|haystack boiler]]'''{{anchor|haystack boiler}}: Early balloon- or haystack-shaped, circular in plan with a domed top and often a flat base. See also [[#Napier boiler|Napier]] and [[#gothic boiler|gothic]], quite different designs also described as "haystack" boilers. * '''[[heat-recovery boiler]]'''{{anchor|heat-recovery boiler}}: a boiler without its own furnace, used to recover heat from some earlier process, such as a large marine Diesel engine or an industrial furnace.{{sfn|Milton, Marine Steam Boilers|pages=119–137}} * '''Hornsby boiler''': a form of [[#bundled-tube water-tube boiler|bundled-tube water-tube boiler]].{{sfn|Kennedy, Modern Engines, Vol VI|pages=}} * '''[[Huber boiler]]''':{{anchor|Huber boiler}} a [[#return-tube boiler|return-tube boiler]] used in the Huber company's [[traction engine]]s. | [[File:Haystack boiler.jpg|center|thumb|center|180px|'''[[#haystack boiler|haystack boiler]]''']] |} == I == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Definitions ! Points of Interest |- |width="895"| * '''[[Illingworth boiler]]''': a water-tube boiler.{{sfn|Harris, Model Boilers|pages=58–59}} * '''[[Scotch marine boiler#Inglis|Inglis]]''': a modified form of the [[#Scotch boiler|Scotch boiler]], with an additional combustion chamber.{{sfn|Milton, Marine Steam Boilers|page=59}}{{sfn|Harris, Model Boilers|page=47}} |} == J == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Definitions ! Points of Interest |- |width="895"| * '''[[Johnson boiler]]'''{{anchor|Johnson boiler}}: one of the first "modern" classes of high-pressure marine oil-fired water-tube boilers. They have a single steam drum above a single water drum. Their small-diameter water-tubes curve outwards on each side to form a cylindrical furnace. As there is no grate or ashpan beneath, firing must be by oil. Return circulation is by external downcomers. Early versions also used [[water-wall furnace|water-wall]]s at each end of the furnace, later ones had plain firebrick walls.{{sfn||Milton, Marine Steam Boilers|pages=111-115}} |} == K == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Definitions ! Points of Interest |- |width="895"| * '''[[Kier (industrial)|Kier]]''':{{anchor|Kier}} (sometimes Keeve or Kieve) an un-fired boiler, a pressure vessel heated by an external steam supply, used for bleaching in dyeworks and processing [[paper pulp]]. In use they were continuously rotated by an engine, steam being supplied through a rotating joint in the axle. They were usually spherical, sometimes cylindrical, and some were recycled from old boiler shells.{{cite book | first=Alan | last=McEwen | year=2009 | title=Historic Steam Boiler Explosions | publisher=Sledgehammer Engineering Press | isbn=978-0-9532725-2-5 |ref={{harvid|McEwen, Historic Steam Boiler Explosions}} }} * '''Kingdom boiler''': an uncommon pattern of water-tube boiler.{{sfn|Harris, Model Boilers|pages=60–61}} * '''[[Kewanee Boiler Corporation]]''': Maker of fire tube boilers |- |} == L == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Definitions ! Points of Interest |- |width="895"| * '''[[LaMont boiler|La Mont boiler]]'''{{anchor|La Mont boiler}}: a [[#forced-circulation boiler|forced-water-circulation boiler]].{{sfn|Milton, Marine Steam Boilers|pages=138-141}} They are often used as marine [[heat-recovery boiler]]s.{{sfn|Milton, Marine Steam Boilers|pages=138-141}} It was also used, unsuccessfully, for an experimental steam locomotive in East Germany in the 1950s. * '''[[Lancashire boiler]]'''{{anchor|Lancashire boiler}}: a development of the [[#Cornish boiler|Cornish boiler]], with two flues. * '''[[large-tube water-tube boiler]]'''{{anchor|large-tube water-tube boiler}}: early [[#water-tube boiler|water-tube boiler]]s with large diameter water-tubes, of 3 inches and above, rather than the later [[#small-tube water-tube boiler|small-tube]] designs. * '''[[Larsen & Toubro MHI Boilers]]'''{{anchor|Larsen & Toubro MHI Boilers}}: [[#Supercritical Boilers|Super Critical Boilers]]. * '''[[launch-type boiler]]'''{{anchor|launch-type boiler}}: a small [[fire-tube boiler]] used in launches and smaller [[steam yacht]]s. A horizontal cylinder in form, with a cylindrical furnace and multiple fire-tubes. They have some resemblance to a small [[Scotch marine boiler|Scotch boiler]] or [[#Huber boiler|Huber boiler]], but with the fire-tubes extending beyond the furnace end, rather than folded back as a [[#return-tube boiler|return-tube boiler]].{{sfn||Harris, Model Boilers|pages=150-151}} : Sometimes small [[#return-tube boiler|return-tube boiler]]s of just this form are also described as "launch-type". * '''[[Lentz boiler]]'''{{anchor|Lentz boiler}} A large [[#launch-type boiler|launch-type boiler]] with a [[corrugated furnace]], used rarely for some steam locomotives. Of German design.{{cite book |title=The British Steam Railway Locomotive |last=Ahrons |first=E.L. |authorlink=E.L. Ahrons |volume=I, to 1925 |publisher=[[Ian Allan Publishing|Ian Allan]] |year=1966 |ref=Ahrons, British Steam Railway Locomotive |page=351 }} A similar boiler, the [[#Vanderbilt boiler|Vanderbilt]], was used in the USA. * '''[[Locomobile steam-car boiler]]''' * '''[[locomotive boiler]]'''{{anchor|locomotive boiler}}: the commonly known form familiar from [[steam locomotive]]s.
A horizontal boiler drum contains multiple fire-tubes and a separate firebox. * '''[[Löffler boiler]]'''{{anchor|Löffler boiler}}: a [[#forced-circulation boiler|forced-steam-circulation boiler]]. It was used unsuccessfully on a [[DRG H 02 1001|German steam locomotive]] of the 1930s.{{cite web |title=German high-pressure locomotives |url=http://www.douglas-self.com/MUSEUM/LOCOLOCO/germHP/germhigh.htm#02 |publisher= Loco Locomotive gallery }}{{sfn|Milton, Marine Steam Boilers|pages=138-141}} * '''[[Lune Valley boiler]]'''{{sfn|Harris, Model Boilers|page=56–58}} | [[File:Lancashire boiler-Marsden.png|center|thumb|center|180px|'''Lancashire boiler''']] [[File:Locomotive-boiler.jpg|center|thumb|center|180px|'''Locomotive boiler''']] |} == M == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Definitions ! Points of Interest |- |width="895"| * [[Monotube steam generator]]{{anchor|monotube boiler}}{{anchor|monotube steam generator}}: A single tube, usually in a multi-layer spiral, that forms a once-through [[#steam generator|steam generator]]. The first of these was the Herreshoff steam generator of 1873.{{cite journal |journal=[[Light Steam Power]] |title=Monotube steam generator |date=July–September 1975 |volume=XXIV |issue=3 |pages=157–159 }} * '''Multi-tube boiler'''{{anchor|multi-tube boiler}}: [[#fire-tube boiler|fire-tube boiler]] with multiple small fire-tubes, rather than a single large [[flued boiler|flue]]. * '''[[Three-drum boilers#Mumford boiler|Mumford boiler]]'''{{anchor|Mumford boiler}}: A form of [[#three-drum boiler|three-drum water-tube boiler]] by [[A. G. Mumford]] of [[Colchester]].{{cite web |url=http://www.gracesguide.co.uk/A._G._Mumford |website=Grace's Guide |title=A. G. Mumford |accessdate=20 March 2016 }} The water-tubes are highly curved and the flue only covers the centre of the steam drum, not enclosing its whole length.{{cite book |title=The Book of Modern Engines and Power Generators |year=1912 |last=Kennedy |first=Rankin |authorlink= |publisher=Caxton |location=London |volume=V |ref=Kennedy, Modern Engines, Vol V |pages=43–45 }} | [[File:White steam car steam generator (Rankin Kennedy, Modern Engines, Vol III).jpg|center|thumb|180px|monotube boiler (White steam car)]] [[File:Mumford boiler (Rankin Kennedy, Modern Engines, Vol V).jpg|center|thumb|180px|Mumford]] |} == N == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Definitions ! Points of Interest |- |width="895"| * '''[[Napier boiler]]'''{{anchor|Napier boiler}}: A high-domed low-pressure boiler used on early steamships.{{sfn|Harris, Model Boilers|page=54}} : Also known as the "haystack", although not the usual, and even earlier, [[#haystack boiler|haystack boiler]].{{sfn|Harris, Model Boilers|page=54}} * '''[[Niclausse boiler]]''': a [[#field-tube boiler|field-tube boiler]], with the field-tubes set at a shallow angle to horizontal.{{sfn|Harris, Model Boilers|pages=63,65}} * '''[[Normand boiler]]'''{{anchor|Normand boiler}}: an early [[#three-drum boiler|three-drum boiler]] used mainly by the French Navy.{{sfnp|Brown|1997|page=140}}{{cite book |title=Modern Marine Engineering |last=Cisin |first=Harry G. |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WWqU8kM5dHsC&lpg=PA84&ots=9M3lqWPE19&dq=normand%20boiler&pg=PA84#v=onepage&q=normand%20boiler&f=false |publisher=[[Van Nostrand]] |location=New York |year=1921 |ref=Cisin, Modern Marine Engineering |pages=84 }} * '''Normand-Sigaudy boiler''': a [[Siamesing (engineering)|siamesed]] [[#Normand boiler|Normand]] boiler, for larger ships.{{cite book |title=Water-tube boilers |first=Leslie S. |last=Robertson |url=https://archive.org/stream/watertubeboiler01robegoog/watertubeboiler01robegoog_djvu.txt |pages=38 |ref={{harvid|Robertson, Water-tube boilers}} }} | [[File:Normand boiler (Britannica, 1911).png|center|thumb|180px|[[#Normand boiler|Normand boiler]]|alt=End and side views of the Normand three-drum water-tube boiler. The convoluted curved shape of the tubes can be seen. Also the hemispherical domed ends to the drums, and the separate steam dome above.]] |} == O == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Definitions ! Points of Interest |- |width="895"| * '''[[One Atmosphere Boiler]]'''{{anchor|One Atmosphere Boiler}}: A compact boiler capable of producing superheated steam to over 1000C at one atmosphere's pressure.{{cite web |title=One Atmosphere Boiler - Superheated Steam Boiler |url=http://www.mhi-inc.com/oab-superheated-steam-generator.html |publisher= Micropyretics Heaters Industrial }} |} == P == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Definitions ! Points of Interest |- |width="895"| * '''[[Paris boiler]]''':{{sfn|Harris, Model Boilers|pages=63–64}} * '''[[Paxman "economic" boiler]]''': a form of Scotch boiler, adapted for stationary use and set in a brick surround as an external flue. * '''[[pistol boiler]]''': a form of small [[#locomotive boiler|locomotive boiler]] with a circular firebox, to avoid the need for [[stay (boiler)|stay]]ing. | |} == R == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Definitions ! Points of Interest |- |width="895" style="vertical-align: top;" | * '''[[Ramzin boiler]]'''{{anchor|Ramzin boiler}} or 'straight-through boiler': a once-through [[#Monotube boiler|monotube boiler]] with a [[water-wall furnace]]. It was distinguished from similar boilers, such as the [[Benson boiler|Benson]], by its use of near-horizontal tubes in a shallow helix.{{Cite book |title=Steam Power Engineering |author=Seikan Ishigai |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=1999 |isbn=0521135184 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=d-IAtrEQ958C&pg=PA35&lpg=PA35 |pages=33–35 }} It was invented by the Russian [[Leonid Ramzin]], whilst imprisoned in a [[sharashka]]. * '''[[Rastrick boiler]]'''{{anchor|Rastrick boiler}}: a vertical [[#heat-recovery boiler|heat-recovery boiler]], typically used in [[ironworks]]. Owing to the conditions of their use, they acquired a poor reputation for safety and [[boiler explosion|explosion]]s.{{sfn|McEwen, Historic Steam Boiler Explosions|pages= }} * '''[[Reed water tube boiler|Reed boiler]]'''{{anchor|Reed boiler}}: An early naval [[#water-tube boiler|water-tube boiler]].{{sfnp|Brown|1997|page=140}} * '''[[return-flue boiler]]''': [[flued boiler]] with a single large flue that folds back on itself. Used in early steam locomotives. * '''[[return-tube boiler]]'''{{anchor|return-tube boiler}}: [[fire-tube boiler]] with multiple small fire-tubes that reverse the direction of gas flow within the boiler. Individual tubes are not folded: there is usually a furnace, a combustion chamber that reverses the flow, then the tubes return from that. The [[Scotch marine boiler|Scotch]] is a well-known example of this type. * '''[[Vertical boiler with horizontal fire-tubes#Robertson boiler|Robertson boiler]]''' * '''[[round-topped boiler]]s''' are a form of [[locomotive boiler]], where the outer wrapper of the [[firebox (steam engine)|firebox]] is a semi-circular continuation of the cylindrical [[boiler barrel]]. | [[File:Return flue boiler.jpg|center|thumb|180px|[[#return-flue boiler|'''return-flue''' boiler]]]] [[File:Robertson autocar boiler, section (Rankin Kennedy, Modern Engines, Vol III).jpg|center|thumb|180px|'''Robertson''' boiler]] |} == S == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Definitions ! Points of Interest |- |width="895"| * '''[[Schmidt high-pressure system|Schmidt boiler]]''': a high-pressure locomotive boiler, as used for the experimental [[LMS 6399 Fury]]. To avoid the usual problems of scale formation in a highly stressed firebox, the Schmidt system uses a separate primary circuit filled with [[distilled water]].{{cite web |title=Schmidt high-pressure system |url=http://www.douglas-self.com/MUSEUM/LOCOLOCO/hptech.htm |publisher= Loco Locomotive gallery }} * '''[[Scotch marine boiler]]'''{{anchor|Scotch boiler}} * '''[[Scott boiler]]''':{{sfn|Harris, Model Boilers|pages=167-168}} * '''[[Sentinel boiler]]'''{{anchor|Sentinel boiler}} * '''[[Sentinel-Cammel boiler]]''' * '''[[Sentinel-Doble boiler]]'''{{anchor|Sentinel-Doble boiler}} * '''[[Shand Mason|Shand & Mason]]''':{{sfn|Harris, Model Boilers|page=57}} * '''[[shell boiler]]'''{{anchor|shell boiler}}: * '''[[small-tube water-tube boiler]]'''{{anchor|small-tube water-tube boiler}}: [[water-tube boiler]]s with small-diameter tubes, 2 inch or less, rather than the older [[#large-tube_water-tube_boiler|large-tube]] designs, with tubes of 3 inch and above. Also termed ''[[#express boiler|Express]]'' or ''Speedy'' boilers. * '''{{visible anchor|Smithies boiler}}''': A development of the [[#pot boiler|pot boiler]] with added watertubes, used for model steam locomotives.{{sfn|Harris, Model Boilers|pages=169-171}} The boiler was invented by F. Smithies in 1900 and developed by [[Henry Greenly|Greenly]]. It consists of a cylindrical water drum hidden inside a larger drum that forms the visible part of the model. Long slightly-sloping water-tubes are mounted beneath this water drum. The advantage of the boiler over similar model boilers is the use of almost the entire water drum surface for heating, although this also tends to scorch any paintwork on the outer drum, unless this is insulated.{{Cite book |title=Model Steam Locomotives |last=Greenly |first=Henry |authorlink=Henry Greenly |publisher=Cassell |year=1922 |ref=harv |pages=52–56 }} In a later development by Greenly, the backhead of the boiler becomes a double-walled water space and straight water-tubes are led into this at an angle. * '''[[Spanner boiler]]''': a [[#vertical multi-tubular boiler|vertical multitubular fire-tube boiler]], notable for its use of "Swirlyflo" [[fire-tube#Swirlyflo|fire-tube]]s.{{sfn|Milton, Marine Steam Boilers|pages=130-132}} Spanner boilers were also known for their use as [[Steam generator (railroad)|train-heating boiler]]s. * '''[[spherical boiler]]''':{{sfn|Hills, Power from Steam|pages=130–131}} * '''[[Stanley steam-car boiler]]''': an extremely compact [[#vertical multi-tubular boiler|vertical multitubular fire-tube boiler]], used in the [[Stanley steam car]]. * '''[[Steam generator (boiler)|Steam generator]]'''{{anchor|steam generator}}: modern boilers, with very small volume in relation to their heating area. Boiling is thus almost instantaneous and the volume of heated, but unboiled, water is minimal.{{sfnp|Naval Marine Engineering Practice|1971|pages=8–10}} * '''[[Stirling boiler]]''': an early [[#large-tube water-tube boiler|large-water-tube boiler]], used in large stationary installations. * '''[[Steam generator (boiler)#Stone-Vapor|Stone-Vapor]]''': a [[#monotube boiler|monotube]] [[#forced-circulation boiler|forced-circulation]] [[#steam generator|steam generator]] formed of a single helical water-tube.{{sfnp|Naval Marine Engineering Practice|1971|pages=8–10}} * '''[[Straker-Squire#Steam wagons|Straker boiler]]'''{{anchor|Straker boiler}}: a vertical water-tube boiler for the Straker steam wagon. * '''[[Vertical fire-tube boiler#Submerged tubes|submerged multi-tube boiler]]''': a [[#vertical multi-tubular boiler|vertical multi-tubular fire-tube boiler]], with the boiler shell extended upwards in an annular ring, so as to always maintain the whole length of the tubes [[Glossary of boiler terminology#Drowned tube|submerged]]. Used in [[steam wagon]]s and similar, where the [[Glossary of boiler terminology#Water-level|water-level]] may be disturbed as the vehicle climbs a hill.{{sfn|Harris, Model Boilers|page=51}} * '''[[Sulzer boiler]]''': a [[#monotube boiler|monotube]] "once-through" [[Steam generator (boiler)|steam generator]].{{sfn|Milton, Marine Steam Boilers|pages=143-144}} | [[File:Scotch marine boiler.jpg|center|thumb|180px|'''Scotch marine boiler''']] |} == T == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Definitions ! Points of Interest |- |width="895"| * '''[[Three-drum boilers|three-drum boiler]]'''{{anchor|three-drum boiler}}: water-tube boilers with three drums in a triangular arrangement. The best known of these are the [[#Yarrow boiler|Yarrow]] and [[#Admiralty boiler|Admiralty pattern]]s. Lesser-known examples are the [[#Normand boiler|Normand]] and [[#Mumford boiler|Mumford]]. * '''[[Thornycroft boiler]]'''{{anchor|Thornycroft boiler}}: Several variants of an early naval [[#water-tube boiler|water-tube boiler]].{{sfnp|Brown|1997|page=140}}{{cite book |title=Stokers Manual |publisher=Admiralty, via HMSO, via Eyre & Spottiswoode |year=1901 |edition=(1912 edition) |ref=Stokers Manual }}
Also a small [[#annular water-tube boiler|annular water-tube boiler]] used in [[Thornycroft]]'s steam wagons. * '''[[Three-drum boilers#Thornycroft-Schulz boiler|Thornycroft-Schulz boiler]]''': a development of the marine [[#Thornycroft boiler|Thornycroft boiler]]. * '''[[Thuile locomotive]]'''{{anchor|Thuile locomotive}}: a unique variant of the [[#Flaman boiler|Flaman boiler]] using a barrel that was an elongated figure-8 section rather than circular.{{cite web |title=Thuile |url=http://www.douglas-self.com/MUSEUM/LOCOLOCO/thuile/thuile.htm |publisher= Loco Locomotive gallery }} * '''[[transverse boiler]]''':{{anchor|transverse boiler}} A boiler with the drum mounted sideways in a vehicle, such as that used by the [[Yorkshire Patent Steam Wagon Co.]] |- |} == V == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Definitions ! Points of Interest |- |width="895"| * '''Vanderbilt boiler'''{{anchor|Vanderbilt boiler}} An American design, similar to the [[#Lentz boiler|Lentz]] and large [[#launch-type boiler|launch-type boiler]]s.{{cite book |title=The British Steam Railway Locomotive |last=Ahrons |first=E.L. |authorlink=E.L. Ahrons |volume=I, to 1925 |publisher=[[Ian Allan Publishing|Ian Allan]] |year=1966 |ref=Ahrons, British Steam Railway Locomotive |page=351 }} * '''[[Velox boiler]]'''{{anchor|Velox boiler}}:{{cite web |title=Velox locomotive |url=http://www.douglas-self.com/MUSEUM/LOCOLOCO/velox/velox.htm |publisher= Loco Locomotive gallery }} * '''[[vertical boiler]]'''{{anchor|vertical boiler}}: flued or fire-tube designs where the main shell is a cylinder on a vertical axis, rather than horizontal. Boilers of this external form may have a great variety of internal arrangements. * '''[[vertical fire-tube boiler]]'''{{anchor|vertical multi-tubular boiler}}: a vertical [[#multi-tube boiler|multi-tube]] [[#fire-tube boiler|fire-tube boiler]]. |- |} == W == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Definitions ! Points of Interest |- |width="895"| * '''[[Early steam boilers#Wagon boiler|wagon boiler]]'''{{anchor|wagon boiler}}: an early boiler, enlarged from the [[#haystack boiler|haystack]] to a flat-sided rectangular plan that permitted a larger grate area, but could only withstand low pressures. * '''[[water-tube boiler]]'''{{anchor|water-tube boiler}} * '''[[Woolnough boiler]]'''{{anchor|Woolnough boiler}}: a [[#three-drum boiler|three-drum]] water-tube boiler used by [[Sentinel Waggon Works|Sentinel]].{{Cite web |title=The Colombian Steam Motor Locomotive |author=Douglas Self |authorlink=Douglas Self |url=http://www.douglas-self.com/MUSEUM/LOCOLOCO/colombia/colombia.htm |website=Loco loco gallery }}{{cite web |url=http://www.steamindex.com/manlocos/sentinel.htm|title=Sentinel locomotives & railcars |website=www.steamindex.com |accessdate=10 April 2018 }} * '''[[White boiler]]'''{{anchor|White boiler}}: An early naval [[#water-tube boiler|water-tube boiler]].{{sfnp|Brown|1997|page=140}} * '''[[White-Forster boiler]]''' * '''[[White steam-car boiler]]''': a [[#monotube boiler|monotube boiler]], used in the [[White steam car]]. * '''[[Woodeson boiler]]''': a form of [[#bundled-tube water-tube boiler|bundled-tube water-tube boiler]].Britannica, 1911 * '''[[Arthur Woolf#Boiler|Woolf boiler]]''':{{sfn|Hills, Power from Steam|page= }}{{sfn|Harris, Model Boilers|page=36}} |- |} == Y == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Definitions ! Points of Interest |- |width="895"| * '''[[Yarrow boiler]]'''{{anchor|Yarrow boiler}}:{{cite book |title=The Book of Modern Engines and Power Generators |year=1912 |last=Kennedy |first=Rankin |authorlink= |publisher=Caxton |location=London |volume=VI |ref={{harvid|Kennedy, Modern Engines, Vol VI}} |pages= }}{{sfn|Milton, Marine Steam Boilers|pages=108-111}}{{cite book |title=Yarrows: the first hundred years. |last=Borthwick |first=Alastair |year=1965 |pages= |publisher=[[Yarrow Shipbuilders|Yarrows]] |ref={{harvid|Yarrows, First Hundred Years}} }} * '''[[Yorkshire Patent Steam Wagon Co.|Yorkshire steam wagon boiler]]'''{{anchor|Yorkshire steam wagon boiler}}: A double-ended transverse-mounted boiler used in [[steam wagon]]s, to avoid problems of tilting when climbing hills. Internally it resembled a [[#locomotive boiler|locomotive]] or [[#Fairlie_boiler|Fairlie boiler]] with a central firebox and multiple fire-tubes to each end. In the Yorkshire though, a second bank of fire-tubes above returned to a central smokebox and a single chimney. | [[File:Yarrow boiler, diagram (Heat Engines, 1913).jpg|center|thumb|center|180px|'''Yarrow boiler''']] [[File:Yorkshire steam wagon boiler (Army Service Corps Training, Mechanical Transport, 1911).jpg|180px|thumb|center|Yorkshire steam wagon]] |} {{compact ToC|side=yes|top=yes|num=no}} == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Fire-tube boilers]] [[Category:Water-tube boilers]] [[Category:Steam boilers]] [[Category:Boilers]] [[Category:Steam power]]

{{infobox UK place| |country= England |static_image=Loscoe 503090 b6abed9b.jpg |static_image_width=240px |static_image_caption=Highfield House |coordinates = {{coord|53.0258|-1.3716|display=inline,title}} |official_name= Loscoe |map_type= Derbyshire |population= 5,335 |civil_parish= Heanor and Loscoe |population_ref= (electoral ward, 2011 census) |shire_district= [[Amber Valley]] |shire_county= [[Derbyshire]] |region= East Midlands | constituency_westminster= [[Amber Valley (UK Parliament constituency)|Amber Valley]] |post_town= HEANOR |postcode_district= DE75 |postcode_area= DE |dial_code= 01773 |os_grid_reference= SK4224547796 }}
'''Loscoe''' is a village near [[Heanor]] in [[Derbyshire]], England, lying within the [[civil parish]] of Heanor and Loscoe. [[Denby#Related hamlets|Denby Common and Codnor Breach]] are outlying hamlets on the western edge of the village.
==History== The name Loscoe derives from the [[Old Norse]] words ''lopt'' (or ''loft'') and ''skógr'', specifically in the phrase ''lopt í skógi'', and means 'loft in a wood' or 'wood with a lofthouse'.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DPsavev7yQ8C&pg=PA183&lpg=PA183&dq=old+scandinavian+loscoe&source=bl&ots=X9Iv8cWXDt&sig=yBMsc_yc2-MGDUTdkTFGWJg9wHY&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi-sI7utuPLAhUGkSwKHTv_Dm4Q6AEIMTAC#v=onepage&q=old%20scandinavian%20loscoe&f=false |title=Language Contact and Development around the North Sea |editor1=Merja Stenroos |editor2=Martti Mäkinen |editor3=Inge Særheim |year=2012 |publisher=John Benjamins Publishing |pages=177–184 |accessdate=28 March 2016}}</ref><ref name=mills>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tXucAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA307&lpg=PA307&dq=loscoe+dictionary+place+names+mills&source=bl&ots=D1nm56CwAJ&sig=hA5IrIz7xt8zYG257FvK8nqB9VM&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjmqsj9s-PLAhUCHw8KHU7jCMwQ6AEIMTAD#v=onepage&q=loscoe%20dictionary%20place%20names%20mills&f=false |title=A Dictionary of British Place Names |first=David |last=Mills |publisher=Oxford University Press |year=2011 |page=307 |accessdate=28 March 2016}}</ref> It was recorded as ''Loscowe'' in 1277.<ref name=mills/>
Loscoe Manor formed part of the wider Draycott Estate; Richard and William de Draycott were recorded at Loscoe (or Loschowe) in 1401. The manor was demolished in 1704.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.heanorandloscoetowncouncil.co.uk/red-river-nature-reserve.html |title=Red River Local Nature Reserve |publisher=Heanor and Loscoe Town Council |date=2011 |accessdate=28 March 2016}}</ref>
In the 19th and 20th centuries Loscoe's economy was dominated by coal mining, so that pit chimneys and spoil heaps were prominent features of landscape. Three mines operated in the village: Old Loscoe (early 1830s – 1933),<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aditnow.co.uk/Mines/Loscoe-Coal-Colliery_9235/ |title=Loscoe Coal Colliery (United Kingdom) |publisher=AditNow.co.uk |date= |accessdate=29 March 2016}}</ref> Bailey Brook (1847–1938)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aditnow.co.uk/Mines/Bailey-Brook-Coal-Colliery_9232/ |title=Bailey Brook Coal Colliery (United Kingdom) |publisher=AditNow.co.uk |date= |accessdate=29 March 2016}}</ref> and Ormonde (1908–1970).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aditnow.co.uk/Mines/Ormonde-Coal-Colliery_9231/ |title=Ormonde Coal Colliery (United Kingdom) |publisher=AditNow.co.uk |date= |accessdate=29 March 2016}}</ref><ref name=hist>{{cite web |url=http://www.heanorhistory.org.uk/loscoe.htm |title=Loscoe |publisher=Heanor and District Local History Society |date=29 September 2013 |accessdate=29 March 2016}}</ref>
Loscoe was within the [[ecclesiastical parish]] of Heanor until 1844, when a new church was built between Loscoe and the neighbouring village of [[Codnor]] to the north, and a new joint parish created for them. Loscoe formed its own parish in 1927; initially services were held in the mission church until a new parish church, dedicated to [[St Luke]], was built in 1938.<ref name=hist/>
Loscoe was the site of a [[landfill gas migration]] explosion on 24 March 1986. Although there were no fatalities, one house was completely destroyed by the blast and its three occupants injured. The atmospheric pressure on the night of the explosion fell 29 [[Pascal (unit)|hPa]] (29 [[Bar (unit)|mbar]]) over a seven-hour period, causing the gas to be released from the ground in much greater quantities than usual.<ref>{{Cite news|title=When barometric pressure is lethal|work=[[Irish Times]]|location=Dublin|date=5 July 2003|first=Brendan|last=McWilliams|page=24}}</ref> In the four hours before the explosion, which occurred at approximately 6.30 am, the local [[Met Office|meteorological office]] had recorded average falls of 4 hPa (4 mbar) per hour.<ref name="newscientist">{{Cite journal|first=Roger|last=Milne|title=Methane menace seeps to the surface|journal=[[New Scientist]]|date=25 February 1988|page=27|volume=117|issue=1601|issn=0262-4079}}</ref> Several cubic metres of [[landfill gas]] (consisting of a 3:2 mixture of [[methane]] and [[carbon dioxide]]) collected under the ground near the house at 51 Clarke Avenue, and as the gas expanded it flowed into the space beneath the floor, from where it was drawn by convection to the gas central-heating boiler and ignited.<ref name=newscientist/>
This incident led (in [[United Kingdom|Britain]]) to the introduction of key legislation and government guidance, much research into landfill behaviour,<ref>[http://users.ox.ac.uk/~ayoung/landfill.html DoE Report CWM039A+B/92] Young, A. (1992)</ref> and revised best practice at landfill sites. Over time, these were designed to vent gas to the atmosphere, then to burn off methane and eventually, in the most productive sites, use gas turbines to turn the gas into electricity for the national grid.
==Demography== In the [[United Kingdom Census 2011|2011 census]] the [[Wards and electoral divisions of the United Kingdom|electoral ward]] of Heanor and Loscoe (which as well as Loscoe includes the north-western parts of Heanor) had 2,285 dwellings<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.neighbourhood.statistics.gov.uk/dissemination/LeadTableView.do?a=7&b=13691289&c=Loscoe&d=14&e=62&g=6412744&i=1001x1003x1032x1004&m=0&r=1&s=1459848883453&enc=1&dsFamilyId=2481 |title=Area: Heanor and Loscoe (Ward). Dwellings, Household Spaces and Accommodation Type, 2011 (KS401EW) |publisher=Office for National Statistics |work=Neighbourhood Statistics |accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref> 2,216 households and a population of 5,335.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.neighbourhood.statistics.gov.uk/dissemination/LeadKeyFigures.do?a=7&b=13691289&c=Loscoe&d=14&e=62&g=6412744&i=1001x1003x1032x1004&m=0&r=1&s=1459842957234&enc=1 |title=Area: Heanor and Loscoe (Ward). Key Figures for 2011 Census: Key Statistics |publisher=Office for National Statistics |work=Neighbourhood Statistics |accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref> The average age of residents was 40.5 (compared to 39.3 for England as a whole) and 17.9% of residents were aged 65 or over (compared to 16.4% for England as a whole).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.neighbourhood.statistics.gov.uk/dissemination/LeadTableView.do?a=7&b=13691289&c=Loscoe&d=14&e=62&g=6412744&i=1001x1003x1032x1004&o=362&m=0&r=1&s=1459865860625&enc=1&dsFamilyId=2474 |title=Area: Heanor and Loscoe (Ward). Age Structure, 2011 (KS102EW) |publisher=Office for National Statistics |work=Neighbourhood Statistics |accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref>
==Notable residents== BMX racer [[Dale Holmes]] was born here on 6 October 1971.
